'''Chemical industry in Poland''' - one of the key branches of the processing industry which includes:
* [[organic chemistry|organic]] [[Chemistry & Industry|chemistry industry]] – manufactures products on the basis of [[carbohydrate]]s, [[wood]], [[rubber]], [[fat]]s and other [[organic substance]]s,<ref>{{cite book |author = Zachodniopomorski Uniwersytet Technologiczny w Szczecinie |title = Analiza sytuacji rynkowej dla działalności gospodarczej na obszarze województwa zachodniopomorskiego dla branży chemicznej |location = Gdańsk |date = 2011|page= 11 |isbn =}}</ref> * [[Hypothetical types of biochemistry|non-organic]] chemistry industry – products manufactured on the basis of non-organic substances, e.g. [[mineral]]s and [[ore]]s.
Chemical industry in terms of tons of production can be divided into:<ref>{{cite book |author = Zachodniopomorski Uniwersytet Technologiczny w Szczecinie |title = Analiza sytuacji rynkowej dla działalności gospodarczej na obszarze województwa zachodniopomorskiego dla branży chemicznej |location = Gdańsk |date = 2011|page= 4 |isbn =}}</ref>
* great chemistry - the name refers to the production size of millions tons a year; great chemistry includes the production of [[Fertilizer|fertilisers,]] [[fuel]]s, [[plastic]]s (''mainly [[Plasticizer|plasticisers]]'') and [[industrial gas]]es;<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.chem.uw.edu.pl/people/AMyslinski/nowy/EChJ/wyklad_01.pdf | title = Chemia stosowana, odpady i zarządzanie chemikaliami | publisher = chem.uw.edu.pl | accessdate = 2016-06-22 | language = Polish }}</ref> * small chemistry - production on a smaller scale - dozens of tons; this sector includes mainly chemistry with high added value and more expensive production, e.g. medicaments,cosmetics, [[cleaning agent]]s; * chemical processing - processing finished half-products: by mixing, packing, thermal treatment and other methods.
Chemical industry is characteristic of the high capital intensity and low labour consumption, for this reason, the most of operations are automated.
== Chemical industry products== Divisions within the Polish chemical industry, by types of products and companies, include:
* [[Coke (fuel)|Coking]] industry<ref>{{cite web | url = http://tchie.uni.opole.pl/PECO11_1/PL/Machnowska_PECO11_1.pdf | title = Przemysł koksowniczy w aspekcie ochrony środowiska | publisher = tchie.uni.opole.pl | accessdate = 2016-06-22 | language = Polish }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.min-pan.krakow.pl/se/pelne_teksty22/czII/k22_warzecha_z.pdf | title = Koksownictwo polskie na tle światowego przemysłu koksowniczego | publisher = min-pan.krakow.pl | accessdate = 2016-06-22 | language = Polish }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.cire.pl/pliki/2/karcz.pdf | title = 50% rynku Europy Zachodniej dla Polski? Koksowe divide et impera | publisher = cire.pl | accessdate = 2016-06-22 | language = Polish }}</ref> — for example: the coking plants "Radlin", "Jadwiga", "Dębieńsko" in [[Bytom]], [[Zdzieszowice]], [[Wałbrzych]], [[Zabrze]], and [[Dąbrowa Górnicza]]; and [[foundry|foundries]] in [[Kraków]], [[Częstochowa]], and Dąbrowa Górnicza. *[[Cleaning products]] industry. * [[Fertilizer]]s industry <ref>{{cite web | url = http://biznes.pl/magazyny/przemysl/nawozy-z-przyszloscia-czy-polska-chemia-nadaza/7c8y1 | title = Nawozy z przyszłością. revision.text:
The '''chocolate industry in the [[Philippines]]''' evidences the [[Agriculture|agricultural]] roots of the Philippine society. The growing of [[Cocoa bean|cacao or cocoa]] boasts a long history stretching from the [[Spanish Colonial Era (Philippines)|colonial]] times. Originating from [[Mesoamerica]]n forests, cacao was first introduced by the [[Spanish Colonization of the Philippines|Spanish colonizers]] four centuries ago.<ref name=":5">Peace and Equity Foundation. ''[http://pef.ph/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Industry-Study_Cacao.pdf A primer on PEF’s Priority Commodities: an Industry Study on Cacao].'' Philippines, 2016. 2. Accessed June 26, 2017.</ref> Since then the Philippine cocoa industry has been the primary producer of cocoa beans in the [[Southeast Asia]]. There are many areas of production of cacao in the Philippines, owing to its agriculture. The [[chocolate]] industry is currently on a small to medium scale.
== Etymology, history and development == {{See also|History of chocolate}}
=== Local terms === The word “[[chocolate]]” as we know it today was spelled in different ways throughout time, in different ways such as “chocalatall,” “jocolatte,” “jacolatte,” and “chockelet.” It is a derivative of the word ''cacahuatl'' or ''xocoatl'', a bitter drink the Aztecs brewed from cacao beans mixed with spices, wine, and other local ingredients that can be traced back to Pre-Columbian Mexico.<ref>Boynton, Sandra. Chocolate: The Consuming Passion. New York: Workman, 2015. Print.</ref>
''Cacahuatl'' is an amalgamation of the [[Maya civilization|Mayan]] words ''kaj'' and ''kab'', which translates to “bitter juice.” The suffix ''-atl'' that means water or liquid was added to ''kajkab'', forming ''kajkabatl,'' and then later ''kajkabhuatl'' with the insertion of the diphthong ''hu''.<ref>Hardy, Frederick. Turrialba (1960) [https://books.google.com.ph/books?id=_ol0KGWC-f4C&pg=PA13&lpg=PA13 Cacao Manual]. Costa Rica: Inter-American Institute of Agricultural Sciences, 1960. p. 13. Web.</ref>
The cacao tree, whose scientific Latin name given by Swedish botanist [[Carl Linnaeus|Carolus Linnaeus]] in 1753 is ''[[Theobroma cacao]]'', is one of the 22 ''Theobroma'' species. ''Theobroma'' means “food for the Gods", from the Greek words ''theo'' (god) and ''broma'' (food). This species is utilized as raw materials for pharmaceutical products and cosmetics, however, cacao is primarily used for the production of chocolate and cocoa by processing the beans.
[[File:Champorado2.jpg|thumb|[[Champorado]] is a sweet chocolate rice [[porridge]] in [[Philippine cuisine]].]]
In the [[Filipino language]], chocolate is translated as ''tsokolate'', which is also a hot chocolate drink made from ''tablea''. ''Tablea'' are cacao tablets made from roasted and ground cacao nibs molded into rounds or tablets traditionally used in the Philippines for making hot chocolate. A ''batirol'', a wooden whisk-like instrument, is the Filipino adaptation of the Spanish word ''batidor'' that is utilized by rubbing the stick back and forth between one's palms in order to thoroughly mix hot water with the tablet in a chocolatera to make it frothy. The result is ''tsokolate de batirol'', a thick, creamy, hot chocolate drink, otherwise referred to as ''sikawate'' in the Visayas region.
''Tablea'' is also used in the production of ''[[champorado]]'', among many other cacao delicacies. Otherwise referred to as ''tsamporado,'' it is a sweet, rice porridge dish in the Philippines enjoyed by many hot or cold, usually partnered with dried fish, either ''tuyo'' or ''daing''.
=== Origin of cacao in the Philippines ===
The cacao plant was primarily brought to the Philippines in the 1700s when a [[Galleon|Spanish galleon]] from [[Mexico]]<ref>Blanco, Manuel, and Andrés Naves. Flora De Filipinas. Manila: Plana, 1877. Print.</ref> transported pure [[Criollo (cocoa bean)|Criollo]], considered to be one of the best kinds of cacao, from [[Mesoamerica]] to the [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]]. Although cacao trees were originally grown in Mexico and Central America, the Philippines became an ideal cultivation grounds for cacao because of its geography as a tropical rainforest located 10-15 degrees from the Earth's Equator, with the cacao belt located within 20 degrees of the Equator. Today, cacao trees are cultivated throughout equatorial region including the Caribbean, Africa, Southeast Asia, and the Pacific Islands of Samoa and New Guinea.<ref>[https://www.sfu.ca/geog351fall03/groups-webpages/gp8/history/history.html "History of Chocolate"]. The World Atlas of Chocolate. N.p., n.d. Web. 08 July 2017.</ref>
=== Key areas for production of Cacao === '''Batangas'''
Although the province of [[Batangas]] only accounts for 0.47 metric tons of cacao production {{as of|2016|lc=y}},<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://countrystat.psa.gov.ph/?cont=10&pageid=1&ma=A60PNVOP|title=Production|last=|first=|date=|website=CountrySTAT Philippines|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> it is well known for its ''tsokolate'' ''tablea'' or chocolate tablets which are considered one of its delicacies and is often used to make traditional Filipino hot chocolate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.batangas-philippines.com/tablea-tsokolate.html.|title=Tablea Tsokolate or Cacao Chocolate.|last=|first=|date=|website=Batangas Philippines A Destination For Travelers|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
'''Cebu'''
Cebu along with other [[Central Visayas]] provinces contribute only around 1% of cacao production in the country, however, in terms of producing world-class and award-winning chocolate, Cebu is known for producing quality cacao.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/cebu/business/2016/05/27/growing-cacao-cebu-475932|title=Growing cacao in Cebu|last=Galolo|first=Jeandie|date=May 26, 2016|work=SunStar Cebu|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> Although there are currently less than a hundred farmer associations, cooperatives, and individual growers planting on an estimated 2,000 hectares in Cebu, the province aims to have a greater share in cacao production.<ref name=":1" /> The province is home to ''criollo'' or the “cacao bisaya,” which is a superior quality cacao that has a strong, aromatic bittersweet taste and rich texture.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://business.inquirer.net/209001/cacao-phs-hidden-treasure-goes-luxe|title=Cacao, PH’s ‘hidden treasure,’ goes luxe|last=Olchondra|first=Riza|date=March 30, 2016|work=Inquirer|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> It is also home to Ralfe Gourmet, The Chocolate Chamber, and Casa de Cacao headed by Raquel Choa who is known for elevating Philippine cacao-based products.<ref name=":2" />
'''Davao Region'''
According to the Philippines Statistic Authority's CountrySTAT, 81% of annual production of cacao in the Philippines comes from the [[Davao Region|Davao region]]. [[Davao del Sur]], [[Davao City]], [[Davao del Norte]], [[Davao Oriental]], and [[Compostela Valley]] are the top 5 producers in terms of volume of production in 2016.<ref name=":0" /> There are also more than 20,000 hectares of cacao farms in the region, and Davao City, amongst the 5 provinces, has the largest area of 6,060 hectares.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/business/2016/07/15/1602839/davao-chocolate-capital|title=Davao as chocolate capital|last=Chanco|first=Boo|date=July 15, 2016|work=The Philippine Star|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> The region is also home to one of the well-known cacao agri-ventures in the country, [http://malagoschocolate.com/ Malagos chocolate].
=== Agencies and cooperatives on the chocolate industry === '''Department of Agriculture'''
A government agency, the [[Department of Agriculture (Philippines)|Department of Agriculture]] (DA) oversees the advancement of agricultural development of the Philippines through the provisions of policies, public investments, and support services.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.da.gov.ph/|title=Department of Agriculture|last=|first=|date=|website=Department of Agriculture|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The department provides a range from technical to financial support for cacao farmers since it considers cacao as a high-value crop based on Republic Act No. 7900 which seeks to “promote the production, processing, marketing and distribution of high-valued crops”.
'''Department of Trade and Industry'''
The [[Department of Trade and Industry (Philippines)|Department of Trade and Industry]] (DTI) is a Philippine government department in charge of attaining the country's goal of having a globally competitive and innovative industry and services sector which would lead to the creation of jobs and inclusive growth.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dti.gov.ph/about|title=About|last=|first=|date=|website=Department of Trade and Industry|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> They have created programs and policies in support of the growth of the cacao industry.<ref name=":6">{{cite web|url=http://industry.gov.ph/industry/cacao-tablea/|title=Cacao/Tablea|last=|first=|date=|website=Securing the Philippine Industries|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
'''CocoaPhil'''
Cocoa Foundation of the Philippines (CocoaPhil) is a non-profit, umbrella organization which represents the interests of the local cocoa industry.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.devex.com/organizations/cocoa-foundation-of-the-philippines-cocoaphil-51839|title=Cocoa Foundation of the Philippines (COCOAPHIL)|last=|first=|date=|website=DevEx|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Their aim is to increase the number of hectares growing cocoa with the goal of achieving the [http://rfu12.da.gov.ph/index.php/programs-projects/hvcdp Philippines Cacao Roadmap] made by the Department of Agriculture and the Department of Trade and Industry. The specific objective of the organization is to develop at least 100,000 hectares into cacao farms as an intercrop under coconut trees.
'''CIDAMi'''
An active cacao value-chain organization in the agri-enterprise section, Cacao Industry Development Association of Mindanao Inc. (CIDAMi) is composed of members ranging from farmers to academe with the vision of world quality cacao-producing Mindanao.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cidami.org/our-works/|title=Our Works|last=|first=|date=|website=CIDAMi|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> CIDAMi has several projects, services and training partnered with professional organizations to accomplish its vision like [https://lwr.org/project/cacao-farming-enterprise-advancement-for-sustainability-and-trade CaCao Feast] and [http://www.cidami.org/services-and-trainings/ Cacao Doctors Training].
'''FedCo'''
The Federation of Cooperatives in Mindanao (FedCo) is a secondary cooperative based in Mindanao with the aim to improve the socio-economic condition of its members through the export of the best quality agricultural products like cacao and bananas in the international stage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fedco.ph/about|title=About|last=|first=|date=|website=FEDCO|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Their operation is centered around the empowerment of small farmers by directly connecting them to international buyers.
== Chocolate industry in the Philippines ==
=== Industry background === Cacao, which originated from [[South America]]n forests, is the source material of chocolate products. However, modern cacao is mostly produced by African and European countries such as the [[Cocoa production in Ivory Coast|Ivory Coast]], [[Germany]] and [[Belgium]].<ref>Peace and Equity Foundation. ''[http://pef.ph/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Industry-Study_Cacao.pdf A primer on PEF’s Priority Commodities: an Industry Study on Cacao].'' Philippines, 2016. 1. Accessed June 26, 2017.</ref> As a minor player in the global industry, the Philippines also engages in cacao cultivation nearly everywhere around the [[archipelago]], even during the early 1900s.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lyon|first1=William S.|title=Cacao Culture in the Philippines|date=1902|publisher=Bureau of Public Printing|location=Manila|url=http://www.gutenberg.org/files/33921/33921-h/33921-h.htm|accessdate=7 July 2017}}</ref>
==== Cacao Industry ==== The Philippine cacao industry consists mostly of smallholder farmers who supply medium-scale manufacturers.<ref name=":8">{{cite web|title=Cacao / Tablea|url=http://industry.gov.ph/industry/cacao-tablea/|website=Securing the Future of Philippine Industries|accessdate=8 July 2017}}</ref> However, domestic production is insufficient; local cacao demand outweighs the cacao supply both locally and globally. One major factor that affects caco production in the country is "the lack of post-harvest knowledge, equipment, and facilities to ensure bean quality for chocolate manufacturing." <ref>Peace and Equity Foundation. ''[http://pef.ph/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Industry-Study_Cacao.pdf A primer on PEF’s Priority Commodities: an Industry Study on Cacao].'' Philippines, 2016. 3. Accessed June 26, 2017.</ref> Since that is the case, cacao exports are far less than country's imports. The Department of Trade and Industry Reports that in 2012, cacao imports amounted to 3,662 tons, while cacao exports amounted to only 512 tons.<ref name=":6" />

==== Growing market opportunity for ''tablea'' ==== Recent increase in the number of cafes and restaurants offering chocolate or chocolate-based drinks provided for the relative rise of tablea market opportunities. In addition to that, healthy lifestyle trends in the past years contributed to this gradual increase of demand.<ref name=":6" /> This is seen as a good sign of possible profit translation for cacao farmers and manufacturers.
=== Industry size === ==== Philippine market ==== Philippine chocolate market is dominated by both local and [[international]] companies. The three largest companies in the Philippines processing cocoa are [[Universal Robina]], Commonwealth Foods, and Goya—all of which are located within Metro Manila.<ref name=":7" /> Also contributing to the chocolate market in the country are several well-known commercial brands such as [[Nestlé]], [[The Hershey Company|Hershey's]], and [[Cadbury]] Adams.
''Local and Foreign Cocoa-processing Companies''<ref name=":7">Peace and Equity Foundation. ''[http://pef.ph/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Industry-Study_Cacao.pdf A primer on PEF’s Priority Commodities: an Industry Study on Cacao]''. Philippines, 2016. 4. Accessed June 26, 2017.</ref>

==== Other Local Brands ====
===== Theo & Philo ===== Theo & Philo was started by Philo Chua in 2010. It is the first bean-to-bar, single origin chocolate maker in the Philippines.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://primer.com.ph/business/2015/10/31/theo-philo-artisan-chocolates/|title=Theo & Philo Artisan Chocolates|last=Inc.|first=Primer Media|work=Business|access-date=2017-07-08|language=en-US}}</ref> Theo & Philo chocolates undergo a six step process to develop its quality. The flavors include Dark Chocolate with Calamansi, Milk Chocolate Adobo, Dark Chocolate Siling Labuyo, Milk Chocolate with Barako Coffee and Dark Chocolate with Green Mango and Sea Salt.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.traveleatpinas.com/2016/08/filipino-inspired-artisan-chocolates.html|title=Filipino Inspired Artisan Chocolates by Theo and Philo|work=Travel Eat Pinas|access-date=2017-07-08}}</ref>
===== Malagos ===== {{main|Malagos Chocolate}} Malagos Chocolate is a single origin chocolate producer from Davao. Malagos is a word meaning “malakas na agos” or “strong flow of water." Malagos is a farm at the foot of Mt. Talomo in Barangay Baguio District, said to be along the equator where the cacao thrives best.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://malagoschocolate.com/single-origin-map/|title=Single-origin Map|date=2014-11-06|work=Malagos Chocolate|access-date=2017-07-08|language=en-US}}</ref> The process of planting, growing, fermentation, drying, sorting, roasting, and production of the chocolate is done on this farm.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://malagoschocolate.com/|title=Home|date=2014-10-27|work=Malagos Chocolate|access-date=2017-07-08|language=en-US}}</ref>
===== Fabros Farm ===== The Fabros Farm covers around 50 hectares and 30,000 tree seedlings are planted. has two locations – Agtedtedted, the pioneer farm, and Mumunsi, in Aurora. Cacao is endemic in Maria Aurora and cacao trees are grown in backyards. Mumunsi Chocolate Café is named after the mountain where cacao trees are planted.
===== Ralfe Gourmet ===== Raquel Choa was taught by her grandmother on how to plant cacao. She eventually became a tablea maker and is the founder and president of Ralfe Gourmet.<ref name="MY TABLEA TALE {{!}} Ralfe Gourmet">{{cite web|url=http://www.ralfegourmet.com/my-tablea-tale/|title=MY TABLEA TALE {{!}} Ralfe Gourmet|website=www.ralfegourmet.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-08}}</ref> Ralfe Gourmet produces tablea that is 100% cacao. To produce their cacao, he beans are roasted, fermented, and solar-dried.<ref name="MY TABLEA TALE {{!}} Ralfe Gourmet"/>
=== Local manufacturers ===
==== Universal Robina Corp. ==== [[Universal Robina|Universal Robina Corporation]] (URC) is one of the largest food and beverage manufacturers in the Philippines. They became famous for their instant coffee mix which catered towards Filipinos. They are also the company behind the Jack ‘n Jill brand which currently produces 26 snack products under its name. The Jack ‘n Jill products are classified into 3 categories namely Salty Snacks, Bakery, Confectionery. URC is one of the heaviest consumers of chocolate because majority of their Bakery and Confectionery snacks incorporate chocolate. URC's first breakthrough chocolate product was the Nips. The candy coated chocolate, similar to the famous M&M's, which was popular among kids. This was successfully followed by multiple chocolate products such as the chocolate covered marshmallow, Wiggles; the chewy butterscotch caramel, Chooey Choco; the chocolate coated nougat bar, Cloud 9.
==== Commonwealth Food Inc. ==== Commonwealth Food Incorporated is a multiproduct Philippine based company that produces coffee, chocolate, and biscuit products.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pana.com.ph/directories/commonwealth-foods-inc/ |title=COMMONWEALTH FOODS, INC. | Philippine Association of National Advertisers – PANA Website |publisher=Pana.com.ph |date= |accessdate=2017-11-23}}</ref> Their chocolate production is overseen by the Philippine Food Industries Incorporated branch which is also known as the Philfood division. They are responsible for producing natural cocoa powder which does not go through Dutch-process procedures. They also produce chocolate syrup, mint-candy covered chocolate, Kool Joy; chocolate candy, Flat tops; and Cocoa Butter. They have reached consumers abroad by supplying cocoa butter to consumers from the United States of America and Europe. Commonwealth Food Incorporated also has a division that produces biscuits. The Fibisco Biscuit Corporation is responsible for the production of Filipino-favorite chocolate snacks such as the Choco Mallows, Hi-ro, and Chocolate Chip cookies.
=== Future of Philippine chocolate industry === The supply of cocoa has fluctuated in recent years due to climate and economic factors. The [[El Niño|El Nino]] phenomenon that hit in the year 2009 greatly reduced the cocoa production in the following years. The extreme weather conditions added to the impending financial crises to limit both the supply and demand for cocoa. Cocoa supply is still decreasing even if the demand is rising. Many entrepreneurs and governments have been looking into cocoa production recently as demand for chocolate rises. They are looking to compete with the top producer of the plant which is Africa. They produce more than 70% of the global cocoa supply. On the other hand, Netherlands and United States of America are the largest consumers of cocoa beans; both consuming Billions of U.S Dollars' worth of the product.<ref name=":5" />
According to the United Nations Commodity Trade Statistics Database, the Philippines has shifted from a massive importer of cocoa beans into a steady exporter of the bean. Entrepreneurs had seen the potential of the cocoa bean industry.<ref name=":8" /> The increase in demand and the falling supply was obvious to them, therefore giving them the idea of planting many hectares of the plant. The Philippine government has also been encouraging the citizens to grow cocoa beans because of the shortage. They are assisting farmers and the industry by supplying land and tested procedures in order to increase the Philippine production of cocoa beans.<ref>Quiros, Judy. "Shortage of cacao both a threat and an opportunity." Inquirer, June 15, 2013. Accessed June 26, 2017. Shortage of cacao both a threat and an opportunity.</ref> The Philippines has the right climate and soil for the cocoa tree which leaves the government the problem of spreading the knowledge on how to plant and harvest for cocoa.<ref name=":5" /> Currently, they are making steady efforts to compete with other cocoa producers. The Philippine government is preparing for the cocoa shortage by the year 2020 and aims to increase production to 100,000 Metric Tons.<ref>Oliver, Nielberg (February 12, 2013). [http://www.confectionerynews.com/Commodities/Philippines-as-an-emerging-quality-cocoa-origin "Philippines as an emerging 'quality' cocoa origin"]. Accessed June 25, 2017.</ref> Although the Philippines is failing to meet the local demand of 30,000 Metric Tons, the strong effort and government support is sure to make an impact in years to come.
== Cocoa production in the Philippines == In the Philippines, [[Cocoa bean|Cacao or cocoa beans]] are produced in many locations. These include [[Luzon]], [[Mindanao]], [[Jolo|Joló]], [[Basilan]], [[Panay]], [[Negros (Philippines)|Negros]], [[Cebu|Cebú]], [[Bohol]], [[Masbate]] and many more.{{sfn|Lyon|1902|p=5}} Cocoa also refers to [[Cocoa solids|cocoa powder]] and [[cocoa butter]], which are two by-products of the cacao bean after it has undergone processing.{{sfn|Juan|2013|p=16}} Cocoa and [[chocolate]] processing was first introduced in the country by Commonwealth Foods Inc. (ComFoods) in 1953, while Serg's Chocolate Products Inc. became the first modern chocolate manufacturing plant in [[Southeast Asia]]. {{sfn|Juan|2013|p=31}}
=== Process ===
==== Planting and farming ==== For planting cacao in the Philippines, there are currently 9 registered and approved varieties by the National Seed Industry of the Council of the Bureau of Plant Industry.<ref>[http://businessdiary.com.ph/2191/cacao-production-guide/ "Growing Cacao - Cacao Production Guide | Business Diary Ph."] Your Business Diary. April 30, 2017. Accessed July 07, 2017.</ref> These are based on high productivity, quality of the bean, consumer acceptability and resistance to pests and diseases. [[Soil]] requirements include good soil structure, which is deep and well-drained, but with sufficient water-holding capacity.{{sfn|Juan|2013|p=39}} Clay loam soil with an aggregate of [[sand]], [[silt]] and [[clay]] work best due to its large pore spaces which "promote [[aeration]], [[drainage]], and moisture retention". Organic matter in the surface layer or soil is also important to cacao growth so the soil must be well-shaded to preserve the organic layer.<ref>Peace and Equity Foundation. ''[http://pef.ph/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Industry-Study_Cacao.pdf A primer on PEF’s Priority Commodities: an Industry Study on Cacao]''. Philippines, 2016. 11. Accessed June 26, 2017.</ref> Ideal rainfall and climate on the other hand is between 1,250 and 3,000 mm per annum, 1,500 to 2,000 mm in the dry season of not more than 3 months, and a temperature from 18 degrees to 32 degrees Celsius. This suitable temperature can be found in altitudes up to 700 meters or in areas between 300 and 1,200 meters above sea level.{{sfn|Juan|2013|p=39}} Because Cacao prefers a moisture-laden atmosphere, a climate of evenly distributed rainfall and few winds are ideal. {{sfn|Lyon|1902|p=6}}
After the seeds are selected carefully from highly productive trees which pest-free and disease-free, seeds are planted immediately either “at stake”, controlled seed beds, pots, or nurseries before they are transplanted to [[plantation]]s.{{sfn|Lyon|1902|p=11}} When field soils are forest land with good organic matter, [[tillage]] is not necessary. However, if the cacao is to be planted with other [[cash crop]]s, a more thorough preparation, which includes [[Plough|plowing]] and [[Harrow (tool)|harrowing]] the land, is needed. Roads, drainage, and shade trees are also established. Based on studies about distancing, cacao is generally planted in the following: cacao laid in rows 2 meters apart if open areas, 2.5 meters away from the base if under [[Coconut|coconut trees]], close planting followed by thinning, or 3 by 3 meters or 3 by 4 meters apart.<ref name=":3">Peace and Equity Foundation. ''[http://pef.ph/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Industry-Study_Cacao.pdf A primer on PEF’s Priority Commodities: an Industry Study on Cacao].'' Philippines, 2016. 12. Accessed June 26, 2017.</ref>
Although trees raised from seeds are still practiced, grafted, budded, or asexually propagated cacao seedlings are now also practiced.{{sfn|Juan|2013|p=40}}
==== Pruning ==== [[Pruning]] is generally done with great care using a sharp saw during [[wikipedia:Dry season|dry season]], when branches have come out, or after harvest as to control the height of the tree and facilitate the work. The first pruning, which is done to control the height of where the first branch is formed, is generally at least 5 feet, so as not to hinder harvesting and maintenance. When five or more branches have grown, weak branches are pruned, leaving only "three or four well-developed branches". The surfaces with cuts are then painted with coal tar or lead paint so as to protect the cuts from diseases or pests.<ref name=":4">Peace and Equity Foundation. [http://pef.ph/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Industry-Study_Cacao.pdf ''A primer on PEF’s Priority Commodities: an Industry Study on Cacao''.] Philippines, 2016. 13. Accessed June 26, 2017.</ref>
==== Nutrition and fertilizers ==== The health of cacao trees are examined based on soil and leaf analyses. Mineral deficiencies are documented to determine [[fertilizer]] requirements. {{sfn|Juan|2013|p=42}} Fertilizers are applied on Cacao around two to three months after transplanting and are increased in the second, third and fourth year of a tree. The fertilizers used on Cacao include [[Ammonium sulfate]], Single superphosphate, [[Potassium sulfate]], and [[Magnesium sulfate]].<ref name=":3" />
==== Harvesting ==== Cacao pods are [[harvest]]ed as soon as they are [[Ripening|ripe]] or mature. The ripening period of cacao generally happens during dry season and can be determined either by the aroma of chocolate that pervades the plantation or the changing of pod color wherein they turn reddish or yellow according to the variety. {{sfn|Lyon|1902|p=17}} The pods are harvested using a sharp instrument such as a knife and are cut as close to the stem as possible. This is done with utmost care so as not to damage the flower cushions, pods, and tree itself. Infested pods are removed. About four harvest cycles with 10 to 21 days intervals are generally made per season.
==== Sorting and grading ==== [[Sorting]] and grading will enhance bean quality. When the beans have completely dried, they are sorted and graded to remove flat, slaty, black, moldy, small, double beans and beans with insect damage.{{sfn|Juan|2013|p=48}} Beans are usually graded based on proportion of defective beans indicated by the Philippine National Standards for Cacao or Cocoa Beans. These processing and manufacturing guidelines successfully ensure quality before they are shipped or handled.<ref>Peace and Equity Foundation. ''[http://pef.ph/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Industry-Study_Cacao.pdf A primer on PEF’s Priority Commodities: an Industry Study on Cacao.]'' Philippines, 2016. 17. Accessed June 26, 2017.</ref>
==== Packaging and storage ==== The dried cocoa beans are packed in bags made of [[Food contact materials|food-grade]] or [[Non-toxic|non-toxic materials]] such as [[Jute|jute bags]] or sacks that an imprint of the label, production number, date, the grade of the beans, code of the cooperative, farmer or area. They are stored in weatherproof, well ventilated, free from moisture, insects, or any other factor that can [[contaminate]] the cacao. {{sfn|Juan|2013|p=49}}
=== Output === After the seeds are shipped to different [[Manufacturing|manufacturers]], they are used for making cocoa powder, cocoa butter, the processing of tablea([[Chocolate liquor|cocoa liquor]]) and other chocolate products such as liquid chocolate, and chocolate bars. Tablea and cocoa powder are also used to create a variety of products such as hot chocolate, champorado, tablea de cacao cupcakes, tablea brownies, krinkles etc.
For chocolate bar flavors, [[Filipinos|Filipino]] chocolate [[brand]]s such as Theo and Philo,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theoandphilo.com/products.htm|title=Theo and Philo Products|last=|first=|date=|website=Theo and Philo|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 7, 2017}}</ref> Risa,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://risa.ph/category/barsbarks/|title=Barks & Bars|last=|first=|date=|website=Risa|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 7, 2017}}</ref> CocoDolce,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freefoodco.com/products|title=Welcome to our selection of healthy products- all natural organic, coconut sap sugar & nectar and delicious chocolates|last=|first=|date=|website=Freefood.co|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 7, 2017}}</ref> Kablon, and others, offer unique flavors that include [[Chili pepper|chili]], [[mango]], [[calamansi]], [[Kapeng barako|barako coffee]], [[Philippine adobo|adobo]], [[Canarium ovatum|pili nuts]], [[pastillas]], [[bacon]], [[Turon (food)|turon]], and [[coconut]].

{{unreferenced|date=January 2017}} {{Finance sidebar}} A '''[[Credit (finance)|credit]] note''' or '''credit memorandum (memo)''' is a commercial document issued by a [[seller]] to a [[buyer]]. Credit notes act as a [[Source document]] for the Sales return journal. In other words the credit note is evidence of the reduction in sales.
It can also be a document from a [[bank]] to a [[depositor]] to indicate the depositor's balance is being in event other than a deposit, such as the collection by the bank of the depositor's note receivable.
== Features ==
A credit note lists the products, quantities and agreed prices for products or services the seller provided the buyer, but the buyer returned or did not receive. It may be issued in the case of damaged goods, errors or allowances. In respect of the previously issued invoice, a Credit Memo will reduce or eliminate the amount the buyer has to pay. ''Note:'' A Credit Memo is not to be substituted as a formal document. The Credit Memo rarely contains: PO #, Date, Billing Address, Shipping Address, Terms of Payment, List of products with quantities and prices. Usually it references the original Invoice and sometimes states the reason for issue.
This is received if the goods are incomplete, damaged, or not as per specification; customers may also receive one if they paid too much money, or if they had been overcharged.
== Uses ==
* To allow the buyer to purchase an item or service from that seller on a future date, i.e. a [[gift card]] or store card credit. Credit notes may be issued by a seller as a goodwill gesture to a buyer who wishes to return previously purchased merchandise (instead of cash repayment) in circumstances where the original sales agreement did not include an explicit refund policy for returned items. In such circumstances, a credit note of value equal to the price of the returned item is usually issued allowing the buyer to exchange his purchase for other items available with the sale.
== See also== * [[Accounting]] * [[Credit (finance)]] * [[Debit note]]

{{no footnotes|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Eddie Hertzberger | birth_date = {{birth date|1904|10|17|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Rotterdam]], [[Netherlands]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1993|05|02|1904|10|17|df=y}} | death_place = [[Switzerland]] | occupation = Industrialist | spouse = [[Eleonore Hertzberger-Katz]] (b. 1917) }}
'''Eddie Hertzberger''' (17 October 1904 – 2 May 1993) was a wealthy [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[industrialist]] and [[racecar]] driver. He won the [[1936 Grand Prix season|1936]] [[Grand Prix des Frontières|Frontières]] [[Grand Prix motor racing|Grand Prix]] for [[sports cars]] at [[Chimay]], [[Belgium]], and the [[1937 Grand Prix season|1937]] [[Voiturette]] race at the same event. He also competed in the [[1935 24 Hours of Le Mans|1935]] and [[1937 24 Hours of Le Mans|1937]] [[24 Hours of Le Mans]] races. In the twenties Hertzberger also did some [[boxing]], while he did a lot of [[sailing]] and [[skiing]] throughout his life.
Hertzberger owned cars like a [[Bugatti]] Type 57 Stelvio 4-seater, with which he participated in the 12-hour night drive organised by the KNAC (Royal Dutch Automobile Club) in September 1926, the [[MG Magnette|MG Magnette K3]], a 4.5 litre [[Bentley]] and an [[Aston Martin]]. He restricted his racing to [[England]], [[France]], [[Italy]] and [[Belgium]], with [[motor racing]] in [[the Netherlands]] virtually non-existent, and [[Jew]]s not allowed to participate in motor racing in [[Nazi Germany]].
At [[Monthléry]], Hertzberger managed to break some speed records in his K3. He also started in the [[Mille Miglia]] and at [[Le Mans]]. He quit racing in 1938 after getting married, although he made a surprise appearance at [[Zandvoort]] in 1953.
Hertzberger was the first of only two Dutch racing drivers to win races titled '[[Grand Prix motor racing|Grand Prix]]', the other being [[Carel Godin de Beaufort]], until [[Max Verstappen]] won the [[2016 Spanish Grand Prix|2016 Spanish]] [[Formula One]] [[Grand Prix motor racing|Grand Prix]]
== Personal life ==
Hertzberger owned a successful clothing factory in Rotterdam. The factory, including his Bugatti Stelvio #57519 which was parked inside, was completely destroyed at the outbreak of [[World War II]] during the [[Rotterdam Blitz|bombardment of Rotterdam]] that prompted the surrender of Holland to the Nazis. Hertzberger escaped the Netherlands through Belgium and France to [[Switzerland]], where he stayed for more than a year. Later he travelled through [[Vichy France]] to reach [[Spain]]. In [[Madrid]] Hertzberger became a member of the intelligence service of the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] government, which was based in [[London]] during World War II.
After the war, Hertzberger rebuilt his factory and lived both in the Netherlands and [[New York City]]. Later he moved to Switzerland, where he died in 1993.
His wife, [[Eleonore Hertzberger-Katz]] (born 1917), wrote a book about their hazardous journeys, which was reprinted in Dutch in June 2003.
Eddie Hertzberger's [[granddaughter]] [[Gwendolyn Hertzberger|Gwendolyn]] also races. She currently competes in [[Formula Renault]].
== Major career victories ==
* [[1936 Grand Prix season|1936]] [[Grand Prix des Frontières|Frontières]] [[Grand Prix motor racing|Grand Prix]] * [[1937 Grand Prix season|1937]] [[Grand Prix des Frontières|Frontières]] [[Voiturettes]] race

He was involved in many important [[takeover]]s, most notably the one of [[Telecom Italia]] made in 1999 with [[Roberto Colaninno]], and the subsequent sale of the company to [[Marco Tronchetti Provera]].<ref>[http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/01_33/b3745082.htm "Tronchetti's Telecom Italia Coup"], ''[[BusinessWeek]]'', August 31, 2001</ref> On October 25, 2006 he was sentenced to six months in jail for [[insider trading]] in the [[Unipol]] (''[[bancopoli]]'') case, together with [[Giovanni Consorte]] and [[Ivano Sacchetti]]. Owner of Abisso Holdings Limited{{cite web|url=https://i-cyprus.com/company/400779|title=ABISSO HOLDINGS LIMITED / i-Cyprus — Cyprus Companies Search|author=|date=|website=i-cyprus.com|accessdate=14 March 2018}}
Owner of [[Olympiacos F.C.]]
Owner of [[Nottingham Forest F.C.]]
Municipal Councillor of [[Piraeus]] | spouse = Athanasia Marinakis | children = 4 | networth = [[US$]]650 million (2015){{cite web|author=Superyachtfan |url=http://www.superyachtfan.com/motor_yacht_amore_mio.html |title=Luxury Yacht Amore Mio II - Evangelos Marinakis |publisher=Superyachtfan.com |date= |accessdate=19 May 2017}}https://www.itsroundanditswhite.co.uk/articles/nottingham-forest-new-owner-evangelos-marinakis }} '''Evangelos Marinakis''' ({{lang-el|Ευάγγελος{{cite web|url=http://www.olympiacos.org/en/member/1634/evangelos-marinakis |title=Evangelos Marinakis | Olympiacos.org / Official Website of Olympiacos Piraeus |publisher=Olympiacos.org |date= |accessdate=19 May 2017}} (Βαγγέλης) Μαρινάκης}}, born 30 July 1967) is a Greek shipowner and member of the [[Piraeus]] city council. He is the owner of the football clubs [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]] in Greece and [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] in England. ==Early life== Evangelos Marinakis was born in Piraeus, Greece on 30 July 1967. He is the only son of Miltiadis Marinakis and Irini Marinaki (''née'' Karakatsani). His father, [[Miltiadis Marinakis]], was a shipowner, a Member of the [[Hellenic Parliament|Greek Parliament]]{{cite web|url=http://www.hellenicparliament.gr/fr/Organosi-kai-Leitourgia/Olomeleia/SInthesi-Proigoumenon-Periodon-New/?slctdPeriod=fdfcad51-0c28-4313-9c23-a47c421e007d&pageNo=13&pageNoR=3&SortByR=perifereia&SortDirectionR=asc|title=Composition des législatures antérieures|website=www.hellenicparliament.gr|access-date=29 September 2016}} and, at times, a financial supporter of Piraeus football club, [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]]. Evangelos Marinakis earned a [[B.A.]] in 'International Business Administration' and an [[M.Sc.]] in 'International Relations' in [[London]].{{cite web|title=Ο Βαγγέλης Μαρινάκης ταράζει τα νερά της ναυτιλίας|url=http://www.enikos.gr/economy/147452,O_Baggelhs_Marinakhs_tarazei_ta_nera_ths.html|publisher=enikos.gr|accessdate=22 November 2013}} ==Career== ===Shipping=== Marinakis is the founder and chairman of Capital Maritime & Trading Corp.{{cite web|title = Evangelos Marinakis|url = http://www.olympiacos.org/en/member/1634/evangelos-marinakis|website = Olympiacos.org {{!}} Official Website of Olympiacos Piraeus|access-date = 11 January 2016}} From March 2010 until September 2011, he also served as [[Chairman]] and [[Chief Executive Officer]] of [[NYSE]]-listed Crude Carriers Corp.{{cite web|url=http://shipping.capitallink.com/interviews/2010/MarinakisInterview032210.pdf |title=Evangelos Marinakis, the CEO of Crude Carriers, Discusses the Strengths of the Company. Interview with Barry Parker of BDP1 |publisher= Capital Link Shipping |date=23 March 2010 |accessdate=19 December 2012}} Between March 2007 and December 2014{{cite news|title=Marinakis makes way|url=http://www.tradewindsnews.com/archive/?q=marinakis|accessdate=23 December 2014|newspaper=Tradewinds|date=18 December 2014}} he was chairman of Capital Product Partners L.P. ([[NASDAQ]]:CPLP). From 1992 to 2005, Marinakis was the commercial manager of Capital Ship Management Corp. and oversaw the businesses of the group of companies that now form Capital Maritime. For the past decades, he has also been active in several other family-controlled businesses all related to the shipping industry.{{cite web|title = Capital Product Partners L.P. - Annual Report for Foreign Private Issuers|url = http://www.capitalpplp.com/secfiling.cfm?filingID=1193125-14-57161&CIK=1392326|website = www.capitalpplp.com|access-date = 11 January 2016}} === Awards & distinctions === Having "grown his shipping empire from the small company he took over from his father, which controlled seven bulk carriers",{{cite news|last1=Whittaker|first1=Gillian|title=Marinakis. The Man behind the Legend|url=http://www.tradewindsnews.com/TWplus/|accessdate=20 May 2015|issue=Spring 2015|publisher=TradeWinds tw+. The Quarterly Tradewinds Publication|date=13 March 2015}} he is regarded as one of the most important and influential shipping personalities worldwide. MARINAKIS|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=MUNICIPALITY OF PIRAEUS OFFICIAL WEBSITE|access-date=}} that he co-founded with [[Yannis Moralis (politician)|Yannis Moralis]], vice-president of [[Olympiacos F.C.]].{{cite web|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/23/greece-vote-port-idUSL6N0O53BD20140523|title = Shipping tycoon makes rare political foray in Greek port town|date = 23 May 2014|accessdate = |website = Reuters|publisher = |last = |first = }} Among their pledges were the preservation of the public nature of [[Piraeus]] Port Authority and the development of Piraeus as Europe’s largest cruise ship destination and home port.{{cite news|title=Moralis : "Our problem is that shipowners left from Piraeus"|url=http://en.protothema.gr/moralis-our-problem-is-that-shipowners-left-from-piraeus/|accessdate=23 June 2015|date=1 May 2014}} During the elections, his political opponent, Vassilis Michaloliakos, claimed Marinakis was related with the far right political party [[Golden Dawn (political party)|Golden Dawn]] and accused him for its financial support.{{cite web|title=Golden Dawn’s consolidation and its reluctant prosecution|url=http://roarmag.org/2015/02/greece-golden-dawn-prosecution/|publisher=roarmag.org|accessdate=}} Marinakis rejected these accusations stating "I condemn Golden Dawn's criminal activity".{{cite web|title=Piraeus mayor accuses opponent of deal with Golden Dawn|url=http://www.enetenglish.gr/?i=news.en.article&id=1951|publisher=enetenglish.gr|accessdate=}} After the election, ''[[Reuters]]'' declared that "rarely has big business mingled so openly with politics in a country where contacts between the two are usually conducted behind the scenes". Marinakis responded, in a [[TradeWinds (newspaper)|Tradewinds]] interview, that he can see no reason why someone with a strong record in business cannot get into politics, "calling that stance "Palaiolithic logic". "I am not afraid to be involved in politics, because I have no business with the Greek state" he said. Since the elections, he undertook the construction of squares, parks, children’s playgrounds and sports facilities, at his own cost, as the municipality of Piraeus lacks the necessary funds due to the economic crisis.{{cite news|url=http://www.tradewindsnews.com/TWplus/355684/marinakis-the-man-behind-the-legend|title=Marinakis. The man behind The Legend|last=|first=|date=13 March 2015|work=|newspaper=Tradewinds|access-date=|via=|accessdate=23 June 2015}} ===Sports=== Since mid-2010 Marinakis has owned [[Piraeus]]' hometown team [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]], and serves as its President.According to the [http://www.olympiacos.org/en/member/1634/evangelos-marinakis][[Olympiacos]] website official biography Marinakis served as president of the [[Superleague Greece]] and vice-president of the [[Hellenic Football Federation]] (HFF) from August 2010 until September 2011. During his presidency of Olympiacos, the team won the Greek League title for seven consecutive seasons from 2010–11 to 2016–17, and the National Cup for the 2011–12, 2012–13 and 2014–15 seasons. In May 2017, it was announced that Marinakis had completed a transaction to become the majority shareholder in English Championship club and former double European Cup winners [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.nottinghamforest.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/nottingham-forest-football-club-press-release-3719464.aspx|title=Nottingham Forest Football Club have released the following statement regarding the take-over by Mr Evangelos M. Marinakis|last=NFFC|access-date=18 May 2017|language=en}} The ''[[Nottingham Post]]'' noted that Marinakis’ acquisition of the club heralds “an exciting future that gives genuine reason for optimism”. Meanwhile, manager [[Mark Warburton]] commented that he expects Marinakis and his team to be ambitious for Nottingham Forest. “..they are aware of the club's stature and they are good football people,” Warburton was quoted as saying. {{Cite news|url=http://www.nottinghampost.com/nottingham-forest-talking-point-fine-lines-mean-so-much-as-evangelos-marinakis-plans-new-era/story-30335904-detail/story.html|title=Fine lines mean so much as Evangelos Marinakis plans new era|date=17 May 2017|work=Nottingham Post|access-date=18 May 2017|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.forest.vitalfootball.co.uk/article.asp?a=581453#ixzz4hQRYlus0|title=Warburton Expecting Aggressive Marinakis Ambitions {{!}} VitalFootball.co.uk|last=Ltd|first=Vitalnetwork|work=VitalFootball.co.uk|access-date=18 May 2017}} === Media === In September 2016, Marinakis, through his company Alter Ego Media S.A., won one of four national television licenses auctioned in Greece after spending EUR 73.9m ($82.8m) in a highly unusual competitive bidding process.{{cite web|url=http://www.tradewindsnews.com/incoming/775802/marinakis-wins-greek-tv-licence|title=Marinakis wins Greek TV licence|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Tradewinds News|access-date=2 September 2016}} The license was however revoked on 26 October 2016 since the [[Council of State (Greece)| Greek Council of State]] held that the TV license law of [[Minister of State]] [[Nikos Pappas (politician)|Nikos Pappas]] was unconstitutional. In July 2017, Alter Ego was confirmed by a Greek first-instance court as the acquirer of the [[Lambrakis Press Group]] (DOL).{{cite web|url=http://greece.greekreporter.com/2017/07/25/greek-court-confirms-transfer-of-lambrakis-media-group-to-vangelis-marinakis/|title=Greek Court Confirms Transfer of Lambrakis Media Group to Vangelis Marinakis - GreekReporter.com|author=|date=|website=greece.greekreporter.com|accessdate=14 March 2018}} The court approval for the transfer ownership of DOL to Alter Ego followed the latter’s success as the highest bidder in an auction process held earlier in 2017. The court ratified the sale and granted a request by DOL staff that the auction procedure be accepted as valid. The completion of the transfer of ownership was also supported by trade unions representing DOL staff. DOL is one of Greece’s historic major media groups and includes the top selling [[Ta Nea]] and [[To Vima]] newspapers, two of the country's oldest dailies, as well as a popular news portal, magazines and radio station. As of March 2018 the agreement for DOL has not yet been approved by the Competition Committee.{{cite web|url=http://cyprusnews.eu/tvxs-epistimi/7297995-%CE%B5%CE%BC%CF%80%CE%BB%CE%BF%CE%BA%CE%AE-%CF%83%CF%84%CE%B7-%CE%BC%CE%B5%CF%84%CE%B1%CE%B2%CE%AF%CE%B2%CE%B1%CF%83%CE%B7-%CF%84%CE%BF%CF%85-%CE%B4%CE%BF%CE%BB-%CF%83%CF%84%CE%BF%CE%BD-%CE%BC%CE%B1%CF%81%CE%B9%CE%BD%CE%AC%CE%BA%CE%B7.html|title=Εμπλοκή στη μεταβίβαση του ΔΟΛ στον Μαρινάκη|first=|last=Administrator|date=|website=cyprusnews.eu|accessdate=28 March 2018}} It also holds a 22% stake in [[Mega Channel]] TV station. {{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-07/25/c_136469236.htm|title=Greek shipowner Marinakis acquires media group DOL - Xinhua - English.news.cn|author=|date=|website=news.xinhuanet.com|accessdate=14 March 2018}} == Philanthropy == He has a role as a philanthropist, both privately and as president of Olympiacos F.C. http://www.internationalpolicydigest.org/2014/09/26/europe-s-football-battlefield/|title = Europe’s Football Battlefield|date = 26 September 2014|accessdate = 10 October 2014|website = International Policy Digest|publisher = |last = |first = }} of instigation and facilitating acts of [[Violence in sports|violence]].{{cite web|url = http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite5_1_11/07/2011_397915|title = Vangelis Marinakis in fresh trouble|date = 11 July 2011|accessdate = |website = Ekathimerini|publisher = |last = |first = }} Marinakis, along with the president of [[Second Division (Greece)|second-division]] club [[Ilioupoli F.C.|Ilioupoli]], Giorgos Tsakogiannis and others, cooperated so that a group of hardcore Olympiacos fans would travel on 13 March 2011 to a [[Third Division (Greece)|third division]] match and provoke [[riots]] to bring about a penalty. The prosecutor’s report says that "Tsakogiannis informed [Ioannis] [[Papadopoulos]] that he had made arrangements and Evangelos Marinakis was aware of the plan for Olympiacos fans to cause riots". Marinakis was acquitted from all charges by the Prosecutor, Panagiotis Poulios,{{cite web|title = Η απαλλαγή του Βαγγέλη Μαρινάκη|url = http://newpost.gr/athlitika/456770/h-apallagh-toy-baggelh-marinakh|website = Newpost.gr|access-date = 11 January 2016}} and the Council of Judges.{{Cite news|title = Απαλλαγή Μαρινάκη σε δίκη 84 για τα Στημένα|date = 31 July 2015|work = Εθνοσπόρ}} In 2014, Marinakis was acquitted by the Three Members Court of First Instance relatively to the case of entering the referee's (Thanassis Yiachos's) locker room at halftime{{cite web|url = http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite5_1_30/05/2013_501734|title = Cup Final referee says Olympiacos chairman entered his locker room at halftime|date = 30 May 2013|accessdate = |website = Ekathimerini|publisher = |last = |first = }} during the football cup final between Olympiacos and [[Asteras Tripolis]], against football regulations to complain about the decisions taken. Marinakis stated that he went to the referee’s locker room at halftime only to wish match officials "good luck". Olympiacos went on and won the match 3–1, after a tense 1–1 at halftime.{{cite web|url = http://www.thepressproject.net/article/65820/The-alleged-corruption-of-Evangelos-Marinakis-and-the-press-that-refuses-to-report-on-it|title = The alleged corruption of Evangelos Marinakis and the press that refuses to report on it|date = |accessdate = |website = The Press Project|publisher = |last = |first = }} In 2015 Marinakis was also acquitted by the Three Members Court of Appeals for the same case.{{cite web|url = http://www.theepochtimes.com/n3/blog/broken-promises-the-sad-tale-of-greek-football/|title = Broken promises – the sad tale of Greek football|date = 2 October 2014|accessdate = |website = Epoch Times|publisher = |last = |first = }} Another investigation which led to the [[2015 Greek football scandal]], started in 2014 after [[prosecutor]] Aristidis Koreas was given the go-ahead by a council of judges{{cite web|url = http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite1_1_08/07/2014_541220|title = Probe into Greek soccer corruption gathers pace|date = 8 July 2014|accessdate = |website = Ekathimerini|publisher = |last = |first = }} to make use of secretly recorded phone conversations{{cite web|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-13914118|title = Dozens named in Greece football 'scandal'|date = 25 June 2011|accessdate = |website = BBC News|publisher = |last = |first = }} that point to the involvement of various sports officials, including Evangelos Marinakis. According to Koreas, "the president of Olympiakos and close associates approached and tried to use policemen, judges, politicians and other powerful figures for their own ends as part of the planning and establishment of a criminal organization". According to the prosecutor, Marinakis was helped by the President of the Greek Football Association, Giorgos Sarris, to choose specific referees to oversee key games.{{cite news|title=Marinakis denies fixing|url=http://www.thepressproject.net/article/65820/The-alleged-corruption-of-Evangelos-Marinakis-and-the-press-that-refuses-to-report-on-it|accessdate=20 December 2012|newspaper=ThePressProject}} He has repeatedly denied all charges:{{cite news|title=Marinakis denies fixing|url=http://www.tradewindsnews.com/andalso/article147701.ece5|accessdate=20 December 2012|newspaper=Tradewinds|date=27 June 2011}} "These allegations have nothing to do with me and have no effect on me whatsoever," Marinakis said. "There is not one shred of evidence against me."{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/sports/soccer/news/_/id/6699614/greek-league-chief-vangelis-marinakis-linked-corruption-scandal |title=Vangelis Marinakis among 68 suspects|publisher=ESPN Soccer from Associated Press|date=24 June 2011 |accessdate=22 February 2012}} On 3 October 2014, Aristidis Koreas, though he was replaced as athletic prosecutor, he remained on the case.{{cite web|url = http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite1_1_03/10/2014_543434|title = Officials probing Greek soccer corruption removed from cases|date = 3 October 2014|accessdate = |website = Ekathimerini|publisher = |last = |first = }} Evangelos Marinakis was questioned on 18 June 2015 and he was released on a €200,000 bail. He was also forced to stop being involved in any football activity, as well as he must report to a police station every 15 days.{{cite web | url = http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/9888897/olymiakos-owner-vangelis-marinakis-banned-from-football-over-corruption-allegations | title=Olympiakos owner Vangelis Marinakis banned from football over corruption allegations | publisher = skysports.com | date = 18 June 2015}}{{cite web | url = http://www.eurosport.com/football/owner-of-greek-champions-banned-over-corruption-probe_sto4787854/story.shtml | title=Owner of Greek champions banned over corruption probe | publisher = eurosport.com | date = 18 June 2015}} In September 2016, the prosecutor proposed the imprisonment of Mr Marinakis.{{cite web|url=http://www.pronews.gr/elliniki-politiki/kyvernisi/479479_kai-xafnika-meizon-provlima-marinaki-gia-tin-kyvernisi-tin-amesi|title=Και ξαφνικά μείζον πρόβλημα Μαρινάκη για την κυβέρνηση: Την άμεση σύλληψη και προφυλάκισή του προτείνει ο εισαγγελέας Εφετών|author=|date=|website=pronews.gr|accessdate=14 March 2018}} In November 2017, the judicial council of the Court of Appeals rejected imposing provisional custody on Evangelos Marinakis and also dropped various charges after deeming them "absolutely groundless".{{Cite web|url=http://news.in.gr/english/article/?aid=1500173843|title=Marinakis: I shall be vindicated on all charges|last=|first=|date=10 November 2017|website=In.gr|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=14 March 2018}} Marinakis was also resigned from president of the team due to legal reasons, giving his seat to Yiannis Moralis.{{cite web|url=http://www.fortunegreece.com/article/episima-o-moralis-neos-proedros-tou-olimpiakou/|title=Επίσημα ο Γιάννης Μώραλης νέος πρόεδρος του Ολυμπιακού - ΕΠΙΚΑΙΡΟΤΗΤΑ - Fortunegreece.com|author=|date=16 November 2017|website=fortunegreece.com|accessdate=28 March 2018}} On 26 March 2018, Marinakis was vindicated by the Greek Supreme Court. The decision of the Greek Supreme Court confirmed that the allegations against him were unfounded.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nottinghampost.com/sport/football/nottingham-forest-owner-evangelos-marinakis-1387363|title=Nottingham Forest owner Evangelos Marinakis issues statement after being cleared of match-fixing in Greece|last=|first=|date=26 March 2018|website=Nottingham Post|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=13 April 2018}} ===Drug trafficking=== In March 2018, Marinakis was charged with trafficking heroin by [[prosecutor|public prosecutor]] Irene Tziva. The accusations against Marinakis were described as "very serious charges" following a three-year investigation after the tanker Noor One was intercepted at the Greek port of [[Piraeus]] carrying 2.1 tonnes of heroin in 2014. He has also been charged with financing an illegal operation.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43527262|title=Evangelos Marinakis: Nottingham Forest owner rejects drugs link|author=|date=24 March 2018|publisher=|accessdate=28 March 2018|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} Nottingham Forest F.C. chairman Nicholas Randall wrote an open letter to supporters reaffirming his support for Evangelos Marinakis. Randall confirmed the matter was under investigation but that "there is no ‘charge’ against Marinakis and no ‘prosecution’ is in process."{{cite web|title=No drug charge for Forest owner Evangelos Marinakis|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/no-drug-charge-for-forest-owner-evangelos-marinakis-gmw2fk6l0|website=The Times|accessdate=18 May 2018|date=29 March 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Marinakis, Evangelos}} [[Category:Greek businesspeople]] [[Category:Greek businesspeople in shipping]] [[Category:Olympiacos F.C. presidents]] [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Greek chief executives]] [[Category:Nottingham Forest F.C.]] [[Category:Greek football chairmen and investors]] [[Category:English football chairmen and investors]]

The '''Further and Higher Education Act 1992''' made changes in the funding and administration of [[further education]] and [[higher education]] within [[England and Wales]] with consequential effects on associated matters in Scotland which had previously been governed by the same legislation as England and Wales. It was introduced during the [[First Major ministry]].
The most visible result was to allow thirty-five [[Polytechnic (United Kingdom)|polytechnic]]s to become [[university|universities]] (often referred to as the "[[new universities (United Kingdom)|new universities]]" or "post-1992 universities"). In addition the Act created bodies to fund higher education in England—[[HEFCE]]—and further education—[[Further Education Funding Council for England|FEFC]]. Universities in Scotland and Wales which had previously been funded by one UK-wide [[Universities Funding Council]] were the subject of other Acts that created higher education funding councils in each country. The act abolished binary line, created national unitary funding councils, removed colleges of further education from local government control, and created quality assessment arrangements.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=104836&sectioncode=26 |title=Richards, Huw, "The collision of two worlds", ''Times Higher Education'' (December 5, 1997) |publisher=Timeshighereducation.co.uk |date=1997-12-05 |accessdate=2010-04-26}}</ref>

'''Hu Yanyan''' ({{zh|c=胡妍妍}}) is the president and director of [[China Guardian]], the fourth largest auction house in the world. In 2015 she was named by the [[Financial Times]] as one of the five most powerful women in Asia’s art world<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/e0b36dae-c0c6-11e4-876d-00144feab7de|title=Asian women wielding art-world influence|last=Harris|first=Gareth|date=7 March 2015|website=Financial Times|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=9 March 2018}}</ref>.
== Early life and education == She graduated from [[Nankai University]] with a Master of [[museology]] <ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/world/2015-03/20/content_19865892.htm|title=Hu Yanyan: the guardian of China Guardian|last=代艳|first=|date=|website=www.chinadaily.com.cn|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=9 March 2018}}</ref>.
== Career == After completing her studies she worked as an editor for publications at the Beijing Municipal Administration of Cultural Heritage. She joined China Guardian in 1993 as a specialist in paintings and calligraphy <ref name=":1" />.
She launched the “Ancient Chinese paintings and calligraphy” auction category in 1998, and the “Chinese contemporary paintings and calligraphy" auction category in 2006 <ref name=":0" />, which has become the company's most popular category <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.artmediaagency.com/95660/profile-on-china-guardian-auctions-an-interview-with-ceo-hu-yanyan/|title=Profile on China Guardian Auctions: an interview with CEO Hu Yanyan {{!}} AMA {{!}} Art Media Agency|website=en.artmediaagency.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-09}}</ref>.

The '''Industry Social Service of the State of Rio de Janeiro''' comprehends SESI's work in [[Rio de Janeiro state]]. The institution focuses in bettering [[workplace|work environment]], [[quality of life]] and [[education]] level of [[Collaboration|collaborators]] from Rio de Janeiro's enterprises. Through programs and mobile units, it carries out actions related to [[health]], education, [[sports]], [[leisure]], [[culture]], [[occupational health]], [[work safety]] and [[environmental protection]]. These activities are aimed at workers and companies, as much as to [[society]] in general. SENAI Rio's history is parallel to the Brazilian industrial development and its designation accompanies Rio de Janeiro's changes, as when it became a capital and was renamed [[Guanabara (state)|Guanabara state]].
== Fields of action == SESI Rio's programs and unities are meant for industry workers, their families and Rio de Janeiro´s population as a whole. In companies, the institution focuses attention on the socially responsible management aiming Brazilian's [[competitive advantage]] and [[sustainable development]]. Besides the quality of life of workers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abqv.com.br/portal/Content.aspx?id=372|title=ABQV celebra convênio com SESI-RJ|accessdate=1 July 2014|website=Associação Brasileira de Qualidade de Vida}}</ref> In a general way, SESI Rio works in four big fields:<ref name="DR">Rio de Janeiro, Departamento Regional do Estado do. '''SESI Rio de Janeiro''' (1996).</ref>
=== Education === * General Education/Equivalency Diploma (G.E.D.)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://g1.globo.com/rj/regiao-serrana/noticia/2014/06/educacao-para-jovens-e-adultos-em-petropolis-rj-tera-30-novas-vagas.html|title=Educação para jovens e adultos em Petrópolis, RJ, terá 30 novas vagas|accessdate=1 July 2014|date=22 June 2014|website=G1 News Portal}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.caxiasdigital.com.br/blog/sesi-oferece-1-170-vagas-gratuitas-em-cursos-para-educacao-basica-de-jovens-e-adultos/|title=SESI oferece 1.170 vagas gratuitas em cursos para educação básica de jovens e adultos|accessdate=1 July 2014|date=24 June 2014|website=Caxias Digital}}</ref> * Preschool * Family promotion (to better the worker's social life and family income through courses) * SESI Rio School
=== Health === * Medical assistance * Occupational health * Odontology<ref>{{cite web|url=http://netdiario.com.br/sesi-oferece-atendimento-medico-e-odontologico/|title=SESI oferece atendimento médico e odontológico|accessdate=1 July 2014|date=18 January 2013|website=NET Diário}}</ref> * Health education
=== Sports/Leisure === * Sporting, artistic and social activities<ref name="DR"/> * Employee participation in championships, as in the case of ''Jogos SESI do Trabalhador'' (Worker's SESI Game),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.caxiasdigital.com.br/blog/inscricoes-abertas-para-fase-estadual-dos-jogos-do-sesi-do-trabalhador/|title=Inscrições abertas para fase estadual dos Jogos do SESI do Trabalhador|accessdate=1 July 2014|date=11 October 2013|website=Caxias Digital}}</ref> with contests in regional, state and national stages;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://g1.globo.com/sp/sao-carlos-regiao/noticia/2012/03/65-jogos-sesi-2012-busca-estimular-pratica-esportiva-e-socioeducativa-sao-carlos-sp.html|title=65º Jogos SESI 2012 busca estimular prática esportiva e socioeducativa|accessdate=27 February 2014|website=G1 News Portal}}</ref> * Support of sporting activities in general (as the population's participation in swimming circuit<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globoesporte.globo.com/rj/sul-do-rio-costa-verde/noticia/2014/06/circuito-rio-sul-sesi-de-natacao-abre-inscricoes-para-segunda-etapa.html|title=Circuito Rio Sul- SESI de Natação abre inscrições para segunda etapa|accessdate=1 July 2014|date=23 June 2014|website=GloboEsporte}}</ref> and athletes' training for the Olympics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avozdacidade.com/mobile/noticiasDetalhes.aspx?IDNoticia=13933&IDCategoria=5|title=Nadadores do SESI são pré-convocados para as Olimpíadas de 2016|accessdate=1 July 2014|date=9 April 2012|website=A Voz da Cidade}}</ref>)
=== Culture === * ''SESI Cultural Rio'' program fosters [[creative industry in Brazil]], offering attractions<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.caxiasdigital.com.br/blog/sesi-do-rio-promove-quarta-edicao-do-x-tudo-cultural/|title=SESI do Rio promove quarta edição do X-Tudo Cultural|accessdate=1 July 2014|date=8 July 2013|website=Caxias Digital}}</ref> ranging from music shows<ref>{{cite web|url=http://g1.globo.com/rj/sul-do-rio-costa-verde/noticia/2014/06/sandra-de-sa-se-apresenta-em-barra-mansa-no-sul-do-rio-de-janeiro.html|title=Sandra de Sá se apresenta em Barra Mansa, no sul do Rio de Janeiro|accessdate=1 July 2014|date=21 June 2014|website=G1 News Portal}}</ref> to artistic awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.otempo.com.br/opini%C3%A3o/j%C3%BAlio-assis/por-favor-sem-flash-1.860899|title=Por favor sem flash|accessdate=1 July 2014|first=Júlio|last=Assis|date=9 June 2014|website=O Tempo}}</ref>
== Programs ==
Due to its social function, SESI Rio focuses on two specific pillars in the state: education and health.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.firjan.org.br/data/pages/40288094212F79010121314833326D3B.htm|title=SESI: ultrapassando os muros da indústria|accessdate=21 January 2014|website=Sistema FIRJAN}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.firjan.org.br/data/pages/2C908CE9229431C901229F14298918C3.htm|title=Projeto Transformar|accessdate=7 March 2014|website=Sistema FIRJAN}}</ref>
Some of the entity's programs are: * '''[[SESI Mathematics]]''': dedicated for high school students and teachers, this program aims to improve the teaching and learning of mathematics in Brazil in an interactive and playful way;<ref name="bahia">{{cite web|url=http://www.correio24horas.com.br/detalhe/noticia/escolas-baianas-vao-adotar-sesi-matematica/|title=Escolas baianas vão adotar SESI Matemática|accessdate=14 May 2014|date=10 July 2013|website=Correio}}</ref> * '''[[SESI Citizenship]]''': takes education, culture, health, sports, leisure and food education to the residents of Rio de Janeiro's pacified communities;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.folhadirigida.com.br/fd/Satellite/concursos/noticias-Cidadania-2013-2000039669693/SesiCidadania-transforma-vidas-2000040450578-1400002102880|title=SESI Cidadania transforma vidas|accessdate=6 June 2014|website=Folha Dirigida}}</ref> * '''Global Action''': along with [[Rede Globo]], it provides public utility services and actions in specific areas (health, education, leisure and culture) for Rio de Janeiro's inhabitants;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://redeglobo.globo.com/acao-global/noticia/2014/04/no-rio-de-janeiro-acao-global-nacional-aconteceu-no-andarai.html|title=No Rio de Janeiro, Ação Global Nacional aconteceu no Andaraí|accessdate=5 May 2014|date=26 April 2014|website=Rede Globo}}</ref> * '''SESI in Action''': reduced version of "Global Action", is mainly focused on providing services in underserved communities, in partnership with other institutions;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.caxiasdigital.com.br/blog/upp-da-mangueirinha-em-duque-de-caxias-recebe-amanha-o-programa-sesi-em-acao/|title=UPP da Mangueirinha, em Duque de Caxias, recebe amanhã o programa SESI em Ação|accessdate=1 July 2014|date=11 April 2014|website=Caxias Digital}}</ref> * '''MBA in Entrepreneurial Management''': course offered by the [[Federal University of Rio de Janeiro]] for the managers of public schools and of Rio de Janeiro's SESI/SENAI network;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.proppi.uff.br/portalagir/uff-e-firjan-criam-mba-em-gestao-empreendedora|title=UFF e Firjan criam MBA em Gestão Empreendedora|accessdate=1 July 2014|website=Portal Agir, Agência de Inovação}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gazetadopovo.com.br/educacao/conteudo.phtml?id=1242773|title=Diretores de escolas públicas do Rio e de São Paulo vão cursar MBA|accessdate=1 July 2014|date=10 April 2012|website=Gazeta do Povo}}</ref> * '''Basic education''': includes kindergarten, elementary and middle school with technical course, in addition to professional education; * '''Evaluation in action''': evaluates the student when he or she enters and leaves SESI School, indicating how the student has evolved throughout school life;<ref>{{cite == Mobile units ==
The mobile units are trailers and vans with office structure to take up to companies health care for employees. Units can be [[dentistry|dental]], [[occupational health]] and [[x-ray]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.celi.com.br/noticias/leitura/id/840/A_saude_do_colaborador_em_primeiro_lugar|title=A saúde do colaborador em primeiro lugar|accessdate=1 July 2014|date=16 July 2009|website=Construtora Celi}}</ref>
== History ==
Until the early 1940s, Brazil was an agricultural, rural and dependent on imported manufactured goods economy. Gradually the industrial sector was being equipped, but it was still difficult to meet all the needs of the worker. Further during the [[Second World War]]. Then, in 1946 (post-war), the private sector exercised its social function and created SESI.<ref group="note">See [http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/decreto-lei/1937-1946/Del9403.htm Decreto-Lei n<sup>o</sup> 9.403, from 25 June 1946], whereby the president of the Brazilian republic ([[Eurico Gaspar Dutra]]) gave "the National Confederation of Industry (CNI) the mission to create, organize and direct the Industry Social Service".</ref> It was industry [[legitimizing]] [[social service]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ebah.com.br/content/ABAAAAoUwAG/servico-social-na-sociedade-capitalista|title=O serviço social na sociedade capitalista|accessdate=30 May 2014|website=Ebah}}</ref> On the same date, its National Department formed the Regional Division of Rio de Janeiro. It was "the beginning of Brazilian industrialization and a new cycle of development that sought to guarantee the country a place in the new international environment."<ref name="DR"/>
=== Industrialization === Between the 50s and the 70s the [[economy]] has changed, with the goal of building an industrialized and competitive society. In 1953, Rio de Janeiro's Regional Division becomes the [[Federal District (Brazil)|Federal District's]] Regional Department, with [[jurisdiction]] on the federal capital. But when the Federal District is transferred to [[Brasília]] and Guanabara State is created, in 1960, it receives the name of Guanabara State's Regional Department. It turns out that, in 1974, then-President [[Ernesto Geisel]] decided to merge the states of Guanabara and Rio de Janeiro (preserving the name of the latter), returning to Rio its ''status'' of the state capital. It is precisely in this time of transition, between 1974 and 1979, that it is created the Regional Department of the State of Rio de Janeiro, current SESI Rio.
=== The so called "lost decade” === During the 80s, dubbed "[[La Década Perdida|the lost decade]]" by economists, SESI Rio "increased in 328% the number of its services in the areas of Food, Entertainment, Health, Education, Service and Community Actions, ie, from 4.2 million to 18 million people."<ref>{{citation|last1=Beloch|first1=I.|last2=Fagundes|first2=L. R.|title=Sistema Firjan: a história dos 170 anos da representação industrial no Rio de Janeiro, 1827-1997|publisher=Memória Brasil Projetos Culturais Ltda.|year=1997}}</ref><ref group="note">From 1980 to 1994.</ref>
=== The 1990s === In the 90s, the policy of expanding through the interior has been strengthened with the installation of units in approximately 10 municipalities.
=== The 2000s === In the 2000s the focus has changed to: * Expertise in Corporate Social Responsibility, with focus on hearing the demands of [[stakeholder (corporate)|stakeholders]] (e.g. [[employees]], [[consumers]], community, government and environment); * Creation of a network of alliances between similar entities; * Increase in the number of Mobile Units; * Appreciation of the sport (as leisure and [[social inclusion]]) through championships; * Creation of [[Distance education|distance learning]] courses for personal qualification.
In recent years, SESI Rio has sought to strengthen its programs for the welfare and quality of life of the citizens of Rio de Janeiro state.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cursogratisonline.com.br/sesi-rj-cursos-e-inscricoes/|title=O SESI do Rio de Janeiro (FIRJAN)|accessdate=1 July 2014|website=Cursos Gratuitos}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atelrj.org/home/convenios-educacao-1/sesi-rj|title=SESI-RJ|accessdate=1 July 2014|website=Associação dos Técnicos Industriais no Estado do Rio de Janeiro}}</ref>
