[[Malay styles and titles|Datuk Seri]] [[Hajji|Haji]] '''Johari bin Abdul Ghani''' ([[Jawi alphabet|Jawi]]: جوهري بن عبدالغني) is a [[Malaysian people|Malaysian]] politician. He was the Member of the [[Parliament of Malaysia]] for the seat of [[Titiwangsa]] in the [[Federal Territories (Malaysia)|Federal Territories]] of [[Kuala Lumpur]] for one term (2013–2018). He is a member of the [[United Malays National Organisation]] (UMNO), a major component party in Malaysia's opposition [[Barisan Nasional]] (BN) coalition.
Johari was the Minister of Finance II (2016–2018). He is a qualified Chartered Accountant and he is a Fellow of the Chartered Association of Certified Accountants.<ref>[http://www.accaglobal.com/my/en/member/find-an-accountant/directory-of-member/results.html?isocountry=MY&FirstName=Johari&Surname=Abdul+Ghani&Location=&inputcountrysuspended=&orgid=ACCA&orby=FNA&ipp=5&pn=1&hid=&requestcount=1 Johari Abdul Ghani ACCA Membership 1991]</ref>
== Early life == Born and raised in the poor area of Kampung Pandan, Kuala Lumpur in 1964, Johari received his primary school education at Sekolah Rendah Kebangsaan Kampung Pandan (now known as SRK Tun Hussein Onn)<ref>[http://www.skthokl.edu.my SRK Tun Hussein Onn]</ref> from 1971 to 1976 and pursued his studies at Sekolah Menengah Aminuddin Baki<ref>[http://www.sabkl.edu.my SMK Aminuddin Baki]</ref> in Kampung Pandan from 1977 until 1981. He continued his tertiary education at Institut Teknologi MARA (ITM),<ref>[http://www.uitm.edu.my/index.php/en/ UiTM Official Page]</ref> Shah Alam from 1982 until 1985 and obtained his Diploma in Accounting. He then furthered his accounting studies in the UK, which qualified him for membership to the Chartered Association of Certified Accountants in 1988 and awarded Fellowship of the Chartered Association of Certified Accountants in 1993.
== Profession and Corporate Career == Johari started his career at an international accounting firm, Peat Marwick & Co. (now known as KPMG)<ref>[https://www.kpmg.com/global/en/pages/default.aspx KPMG]</ref> as an auditor. Johari was active in the corporate world for more than 25 years. He held several senior positions including Group Managing Director and Chairman in several companies, both listed and unlisted in the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange. He also held positions as Managing Directors of companies involved in the fast food industries, manufacturing and agriculture.
Johari is active in various social and community services. He was appointed Chairman of ‘Jawatankuasa Pemakanan Negara’ at the Ministry of Agriculture and Agro-based Industry. He was also a member of ‘Lembaga Pelawat Hospital Kuala Lumpur’ and member of ‘Jawatankuasa Badan Amal & Aduan Rakyat Wilayah Persekutuan’.
Johari sits on the Malaysia Economic Council.<ref>[https://twitter.com/PMOMalaysia/status/869070260124516352 Malaysia Economic Council Members]</ref> The Council, which is chaired by the Prime Minister of Malaysia, is responsible, among others, to formulate strategies to sustain the economic growth of Malaysia through foreign direct investment and domestic investments for the country and to monitor and analyze trends in the development of both global and domestic economy in order to formulate specific actions to spur the Malaysian economic growth.
Johari is also a member of the Board of Directors of [[Khazanah Nasional Berhad]],<ref>[http://www.khazanah.com.my/About-Khazanah/Board-of-Directors Khazanah Nasional]</ref> the sovereign wealth fund of the Government of Malaysia since 2016. He is also the Chairman of the Langkawi Development Authority (LADA),<ref>[https://www.lada.gov.my/mengenai-kami/profil/lembaga-pengarah Langkawi Development Authority (LADA)]</ref> a government agency responsible for the development of the Langkawi Island as an international tourist destination. Johari was formerly the Chairman of UDA Holdings Berhad, a government linked company that is involved in urban development. Datuk Seri Johari is a member of the Board of Trustees for the Yayasan Pelaburan Bumiputera,<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=22498371 Yayasan Pelaburan Bumiputera PNB]</ref> the parent company of Permodalan Nasional Berhad which manages more than RM250 billion unit trust funds in Malaysia. Johari is active in the Yayasan Peneraju Pendidikan Bumiputera (YPPB)<ref>[http://www.yayasanpeneraju.com.my/index.php?data-yayasan-peneraju=58 Yayasan Peneraju Pendidikan Bumiputera (YPPB)]</ref> where he serves on the Board of Trustees. The YPPB is a strategic unit under the Prime Minister’s Office established to strengthen Bumiputeras’ capability and expertise in the economy and education.
He is a founder and currently the Chairman of Yayasan Bena Nusa and a Board Member of the Yayasan Pendidikan Titiwangsa, both of which were established to help to reduce urban poverty and improve educational outcomes for children of the urban poor.<ref>[http://www.yayasanpeneraju.com.my/index.php?data-yayasan-peneraju=58 Yayasan Bena Nusa]</ref>
== Political career == Johari has been active in politics for more than 24 years since 1988. He has held various positions in UMNO and BN of Titiwangsa. In June 2010, he was made the Acting Chief of UMNO’s Division of Titiwangsa and appointed as Barisan Nasional Coordinating Chairman for the Titiwangsa parliamentary constituency. Concerned with community issues raised by the Titiwangsa Parliament, he took the initiative to establish a Community Service Center in Titiwangsa in July 2010 to assist in addressing and resolving these issues. Amongst the major concerns of the Titiwangsa Parliament community were poverty, squatters’ settlement, infrastructure, vendors and others. The Community Service Center operated on Mondays to Fridays from 9.00 am to 5.00 pm.
During the [[Malaysian general election, 2013|2013 general election]], he was chosen to contest and won the Titiwangsa parliamentary seat<ref>[http://www.parlimen.gov.my/profile-ahli.html?uweb=dr&id=3192 Parliament Malaysia Official Page]</ref> and on 27 July 2015, he was appointed as the Deputy Minister of Finance.<ref>[http://www.theedgemarkets.com/en/article/ci-holdings-43-md%E2%80%99s-appointment-deputy-finance-minister Johari Appointed as Deputy Finance Minister]</ref> Following a cabinet reshuffle on 27 June 2016, Johari was appointed as the Minister of Finance II.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nst.com.my/news/2016/06/155004/cabinet-reshuffle-two-full-ministers-four-new-deputy-ministers-announced-video|title=Cabinet reshuffle: Two full ministers, four new deputy ministers announced [VIDEO]|date=2016-06-27|newspaper=NST Online|access-date=2017-02-23}}</ref>
However, in the [[Malaysian general election, 2018|2018 general election]], Johari failed to retain the Titiwangsa parliamentary seat,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/bns-big-names-toppled-one-after-another|title=Malaysia Votes 2018: BN's big names toppled, one after another|first=Nadirah|last=H. Rodzi|date=10 May 2018|work=[[The Straits Times]]|accessdate=10 May 2018}}</ref> losing by a 4,139-vote majority to [[Rina Harun]], the Woman's Chief of the [[Malaysian United Indigenous Party|PPBM]], a component party of [[Pakatan Harapan]].

== Honour and Award == In recognition of his efforts in the areas of community, social, politics, corporate and business, he was conferred the Darjah Kebesaran Negeri Selangor (D.S.I.S) by Sultan Idris Shah of Selangor Sultan Sharifuddin which carries the title Dato’ in 2003. It is located in [[Whitefield, Bangalore|Whitefield]], [[Bangalore]] in the state of [[Karnataka]]. Kadugodi comes from "kadu" & "Gudi" meaning "temple in a forest" in [[Kannada]]. It is believed that this whole area had thick vegetation consisting of soap-nut shrubs. The temple after which the place gets its name was also discovered by people venturing in to this kadu(forest) while gathering soap-nuts. This temple is of Anjaneya which is believed as udbhava murthi. Kadugudi is also referred to as "Aranayapuri" in temple related invites and publications. Kadugodi has many temples and oldest among them are Anjaneya temple, kashi Vishwanatha temple, Ganesh temple, Eashwara temple and the grama devata temples of Maramma and Ganga parameshwari. All these temples are located in old kadugodi area starting from Bapuji circle up to Kashi vishwanatha temple. Two major festivities of kadugudi is when Rathotsava(Charriot festival) are conducted for Eashwara and Rama deities. Lot of festivities are conducted before and after the actual rathotsava day. Going by the street names of kadugudi one can deduce that this place must have been a well planned out settlement. There is a kumbhara beedi(potter street), there is Ganigara beedi(vegetable oil extractors), Angadi beedi(Market street), balajigara beedhi(mainly merchants dealing in bangles, flowers etc.). In 1970s kadugodi saw its first extension towards west as Village Panchyat extension or simple referred to as new extension or VP extension. In 1980s saw another extension in eastern direction when a new extension was formed by free distribution of plots to economically deserving families. This was done by the Eashwara temple family and was named after Shree Shankar Dixit, this area now is popularly known as Shankara pura. ==Climate== '''Kadugudi''' is known for its pleasant climate throughout the year. Its elevation is the highest among the major large cities of [[India]]. [[File:View of street in kadugodi.jpg|thumb|View of inside Kadugodi.]] Kadugudi has a [[tropical savanna climate]] ([[Köppen climate classification]] ''Aw'') with distinct [[wet season|wet]] and [[dry season|dry]] seasons. Due to its high elevation, Kadugudi usually enjoys a more moderate climate throughout the year, although occasional heat waves can make summer somewhat uncomfortable The coolest month is December with an average low temperature of {{convert|19.4|°C}} and the hottest month is April with an average high temperature of {{convert|36|°C|0}}. The highest temperature ever recorded in Kadugudi is {{convert|36.8|°C}} (recorded in March 2012). However, the suburbs of Kadugudi recorded temperatures as high as {{convert|39|°C|0}}. The lowest ever recorded is {{convert|9.8|°C|0}} (recorded in January 2013). Winter temperatures rarely drop below {{convert|12|°C}}, and summer temperatures seldom exceed {{convert|37|°C}}. Kadugodi receives rainfall from both the northeast and the southwest [[monsoon]]s and the wettest months are September, October and August, in that order. The summer heat is moderated by fairly frequent [[thunderstorm]]s. In the [[Germany|Federal Republic of Germany]], the '''Ladenschlussgesetz''' or "Shop Closing Law" (abbreviated: '''LadSchlG''') is the federal law regulating at which times retail stores were forced to be closed to the public. The ''Ladenschlussgesetz'' in its current form was first enacted on 28 November 1956 following pressure from Germany's trade unions; in its last revision (of 2 June 2003), points of sale ''(Verkaufsstellen)'' must be closed at any of the following times:
# On Sundays and public [[holiday]]s; # On working days (Monday through Saturday) before 06:00 and after 20:00; # On December 24 before 06:00 and after 14:00 if that date falls on a working day
The law provides differing regulations for pharmacies, petrol stations, shops at train stations and airports, etc.
On 30 June 2006, as part of the ''Föderalismusreform'' ("Federalism Reform"), the regulatory responsibility for this area was devolved to the [[States of Germany|German states]]. The net effect, although the Federal law technically remains in force, the states are free to determine the opening hours of retail stores in their areas. Meanwhile, all states - with the exception of the more conservative Bavaria - made use of that option.
==German states with varying shop opening hours== The states have each adopted individual regulations concerning opening hours on Sundays and public holidays. Some continue to observe the existing Federal rules, while others have liberalized them somewhat, although the general Federal ban concerning opening on Sundays and holidays remains in effect, owing to a provision in the German constitution recognizing Sunday as a day of rest and a corresponding decision of the Federal Constitutional Court ''([[Bundesverfassungsgericht]])'' on 9 June 2004.
===24/6 scheme=== ''(Shops may be open as desired at any hour (day or night) Monday through Saturday)''
*[[Baden-Württemberg]] Effective date: 6 March 2007 *[[Berlin]] Effective date: 14 November 2006 *[[Brandenburg]] Effective date: 1 December 2006 *[[Bremen (state)|Bremen]] Effective date: 1 April 2007 *[[Hamburg]] Effective date: 1 January 2007 *[[Hesse]] Effective date: 1 December 2006 *[[Lower Saxony]] Effective date: 21 November 2006 *[[North Rhine-Westphalia]] Effective date: 21 November 2006 *[[Schleswig-Holstein]] Effective date: 1 December 2006
===24/5 scheme=== ''(Shops may be open as desired at any hour (day or night) Monday through Friday, with restrictions on Saturday opening hours)''
*[[Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania]] Effective date: 2 July 2007 ''Shops may be open until 10 pm on Saturdays.''
*[[Saxony-Anhalt]] Effective date: 30 November 2006 '''and''' *[[Thuringia]] Effective date: 24 November 2006 ''Shops may be open until 8 pm on Saturdays; rules for Sundays and holidays follow the existing Federal law.''
===Other schemes===
*[[Rhineland-Palatinate]] Effective date: 29 November 2006 '''and''' *[[Saxony]] Effective date: 1 April 2007 ''Shops may be open Monday through Saturday from 6 am to 10 pm each day.''

page.title: List of economic advisors to Donald Trump

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:2010s-related lists]] to [[Category:2010s politics-related lists]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{main|Economic policy of Donald Trump|Political appointments of Donald Trump}} {{dynamic list}} As part of [[Donald Trump]]'s [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|2016 presidential campaign]], various [[Donald_Trump_presidential_campaign,_2016#Economists|economists]] and [[List_of_Donald_Trump_presidential_campaign_primary_endorsements,_2016#Businesspeople|businesspeople]] have served both in a formal and an informal capacity, to advise Trump on [[macroeconomics]] and associated [[government policy]] decisions. During the [[presidential transition of Donald Trump#Transition_team|transition]] to the [[Presidency of Donald Trump#Personnel|presidency]], Trump gained additional advisors, and after the [[inauguration of Donald Trump#Committee_members|inauguration]] some of his advisors will officially become part of the [[Political appointments of Donald Trump|Trump administration]] (including the [[United States National Economic Council|NEC]], [[National Trade Council|NTC]], [[Senior_Advisor_to_the_President_of_the_United_States#Donald_Trump|advisors]], [[List_of_U.S._executive_branch_czars#List_of_executive_branch_czars|czars]], [[Counselor to the President|counselors]], [[Cabinet of Donald Trump#Director of the Office of Management and Budget|OMB]], [[Cabinet of Donald Trump#Chair of the Council of Economic Advisers|CEA]], [[Cabinet of Donald Trump#Secretary of the Treasury|Treasury]], [[Cabinet of Donald Trump#Secretary of Commerce|Commerce]], [[Cabinet of Donald Trump#United States Trade Representative|USTR]], [[Cabinet of Donald Trump#Administrator of the Small Business Administration|SBA]], [[Political appointments of Donald Trump#Chair of the Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]], and the [[Political appointments of Donald Trump#Vice Chair of the Federal Reserve|Fed]]) while others will remain in the [[private sector]] as informal advisors with varying degrees of influence.
==Background== {{main |Domestic policy of the Ronald Reagan administration|l1=Economic policy of Reagan |Presidency_of_George_H._W._Bush#Domestic_policy|l2=George H.W. Bush |Economic policy of Bill Clinton|l3=Bill Clinton |Economic_policy_of_the_George_W._Bush_administration|l4=George W. Bush |Economic policy of Barack Obama|l5=Obama}} {{see also|Economy of the United States|United States federal budget|Economic policy}} {{expand section|date=December 2016}}
==During his presidential campaign== {{main|Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016}} Trump released initial details of his economic policies when his campaign officially began in June 2015, and more details during the first [[Republican Party presidential debates and forums, 2016|Republican debates]] which began in August 2015. Although critical of certain aspects of Trump's early economic plans, especially increasing [[tariff]]s as opposed to [[free trade]] policies,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2015/08/26/donald_trump_a_21st_century_protectionist_herbert_hoover_127893.html|title=Donald Trump: A 21st Century Protectionist Herbert Hoover - RealClearPolitics|publisher=}}</ref> [[Larry Kudlow]] and [[Stephen Moore (writer)|Steve Moore]] would eventually{{when|date=December 2016}} agree to join the [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|Trump campaign]] as advisors. Although most presidential candidates had announced a team of formal economic advisors by October 2015, at the time Trump still primarily relied upon [[Donald Trump#Business career|his business background]] to inform his economic plan ([[Carly Fiorina]] was the other candidate who relied primarily upon her own background in business in the early phases of the campaign).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/pundits-blog/presidential-campaign/257277-the-economic-advisers-behind-the-candidates|title=The economic advisers behind the candidates|first=Mark Bloomfield,|last=contributor|date=19 October 2015|publisher=}}</ref> In addition to his own business expertise, Trump had a network of contacts that sometimes served as informal economic advisors during his campaign, including [[Carl Icahn]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2016/11/21/donald-trump-carl-ichan-role/|title=Billionaire Carl Icahn Is Considering an Official Economics Role under Donald Trump|first=Lucinda|last=Shen|website=Fortune}}</ref> Even as late as July 2016, however, [[Larry Kudlow|Kudlow]] and [[Stephen Moore (writer)|Moore]] were still not official advisors, despite having already helped craft some of Trump's policy-positions related to taxation for instance.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2016/07/21/what-trumps-and-clintons-economic-advisors-can-tell-you-about-the-candidates.html|title=What Trump's and Clinton's economic advisors can tell you about the candidates|first=Ivan|last=Levingston|date=22 July 2016|publisher=}}</ref> {{expand section|date=December 2016}}
===During the general election=== Trump released a list of [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|his campaign's]] official economic advisers in August 2016,<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/06/business/economy/donald-trump-economic-team.html|title=Trump’s Economic Team: Bankers and Billionaires (and All Men)|first=Patricia|last=Cohen|date=5 August 2016|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref><ref name=":41">{{Cite web|url=https://www.donaldjtrump.com/press-releases/trump-campaign-announces-trump-economic-advisory-council|title=Trump Campaign Announces Economic Advisory Council|publisher=Donald J. Trump for President, Inc.|accessdate=August 5, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160805121426/https://www.donaldjtrump.com/press-releases/trump-campaign-announces-trump-economic-advisory-council|archivedate=August 5, 2016|df=}}</ref><ref name=":43">{{Cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/08/trump-economic-advisory-team-226709|title=Trump unveils all-male economic advisory team|accessdate=August 5, 2016}}</ref> which was significantly anti-establishment<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/09/business/dealbook/donald-trumps-economic-team-is-far-from-typical.html|title=Donald Trump’s Economic Team Is Far From Typical|first=Andrew Ross|last=Sorkin|date=8 August 2016|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> and therefore included few people with any governmental experience,<ref name="auto1">{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/some-of-donald-trumps-economic-team-diverge-from-candidate-1476290773|title=Some of Donald Trump’s Economic Team Diverge From Candidate|first=Nick|last=Timiraos|date=13 October 2016|publisher=|via=www.wsj.com}}</ref> yet at the same time aimed to include some of the elites of business and finance,<ref name="auto"/> primarily people with well-known names.
Although most of the names were new, existing Trump advisers [[David Malpass]], [[Peter Navarro]], [[Stephen Moore (writer)|Stephen Moore]], and [[Dan DiMicco]] were also on the list, formally led by [[Stephen Miller (aide)|Stephen Miller]], the national policy director, and directly led by deputy policy director Dan Kowalski. The Trump'16 finance director [[Steven Mnuchin]] was also listed, and played a role in helping coordinate the group. Many of the names on the original list, or on the subsequent expansions thereof,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/08/trump-economic-advisers-revised-list-226912|title=Trump brings women on to his economic council|publisher=}}</ref> received media attention [[Cabinet of Donald Trump|as potential appointees]] to the presidential [[Council of Economic Advisers]], or in [[Political_appointments_of_Donald_Trump|other Trump administration roles]]. As of August 2016, Trump's economic advisors included:
* [[Thomas_J._Barrack_Jr.|Tom Barrack]], CEO of [[Colony Capital]], [[inauguration of Donald Trump|inauguration]] chair, former [[Cabinet_of_Donald_Trump#Secretary_of_the_Treasury|Treasury]] contender, major donor<ref name=politico20160807>{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/08/trumps-economic-advisers-are-also-his-biggest-donors-226758|title=Trump’s economic advisers are also his biggest donors|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Andrew Beal|Andy Beal]], banker, billionaire, professional [[poker player]], major donor<ref name=politico20160807/> * [[Stephen Calk]], CEO of the Federal Savings Bank, officer and helicopter pilot in the [[U.S. Army]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/news/kapos-meet-the-chicago-exec-banking-on-trump-flaws-and-all/|title=Kapos: Meet the Chicago exec banking on Trump, flaws and all|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Dan DiMicco]], former CEO of [[Nucor Corporation|Nucor]], [[Cabinet_of_Donald_Trump#Secretary_of_Commerce|Commerce]]/[[Council_of_Economic_Advisers#List_of_Chairs|CEA]]/[[Cabinet_of_Donald_Trump#United States Trade Representative|USTR]] contender * [[Steve Feinberg]], CEO of [[Cerberus Capital]], major donor<ref name=politico20160807/> * [[Harold Hamm]], oil and [[natural gas|gas]] industry, billionaire, former [[Cabinet_of_Donald_Trump#Secretary_of_Energy|Energy]]/[[Cabinet_of_Donald_Trump#Secretary_of_the_Interior|Interior]] contender * Kathleen Hartnett-White, former [[Cabinet_of_Donald_Trump#Administrator_of_the_Environmental_Protection_Agency|EPA]]/[[Cabinet_of_Donald_Trump#Secretary_of_the_Interior|Interior]] contender,<ref name=mcclatchy2016>{{cite Transition Leaders for Government Management Agencies|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Howard Lorber]], CEO of [[Vector Group]], major donor<ref name=politico20160807/> * [[David Malpass]], [[Political_appointments_of_Donald_Trump#Vice_Chair_of_the_Federal_Reserve|Fed]]/[[Cabinet_of_Donald_Trump#Director of the Office of Management and Budget|OMB]]/[[Cabinet_of_Donald_Trump#United States interviews first aired in 1989|The Coming Soviet Crash]]''<ref name=fortune20160818/> * [[Richard Uihlein|Liz Uihlein]], president of [[Uline]]
Several of the advisors were major donors to Trump's presidential campaign.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Goldmacher|first=Shane|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/08/trumps-economic-advisers-are-also-his-biggest-donors-226758|title=Trump's economic advisers are also his biggest donors|work=Politico|date=August 7, 2016|accessdate=August 7, 2016}}</ref>
At first, only one of Trump's initial list of a dozen official advisors, [[Peter Navarro]], had a PhD in economics.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.vice.com/article/trumps-economic-team-includes-big-short-billionaire-who-bet-against-us-housing-market|title=Trump's economic team includes 'Big Short' billionaire who bet against US housing market |publisher=VICE News|language=en-US|accessdate=August 5, 2016}}</ref> Although he had been in contact with Trump since 2011,<ref name=newyorker2016>{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/business/currency/trumps-muse-on-u-s-trade-with-china|title=Trump’s Muse on U.S. Trade with China|website=The New Yorker}}</ref> Navarro had never met nor spoken with Trump directly in August 2016,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/navarro-725714-trump-trade.html|title=One of Donald Trump's biggest economic supporters? It's a UC Irvine economist|last=Roosevelt|first=Margot|language=en-US|newspaper=Orange County Register|accessdate=August 16, 2016}}</ref> but began to meet with Trump in person late in the 2016 campaign.<ref name=newyorker2016/> A few days after Navarro was announced, Trump added [[Judy Shelton]], an economist<ref name=fortune20160818/><ref name="bloomberg.com"/> with a [[Ph.D]]<ref name=fortune20160818/> in [[business administration]]<ref name="atlasnetwork.org"/> to his team.
==As the [[President-elect]]== {{main|Cabinet of Donald Trump|Political appointments of Donald Trump}}
As of December 2016, many of the advisors during the campaign listed above are under consideration for [[Cabinet of Donald Trump|cabinet-level roles]] or other [[Political appointments of Donald Trump|high-level roles]] in the [[Presidency of Donald Trump|Trump administration]]. (For instance, Navarro is a contender for the [[Council_of_Economic_Advisers#List_of_Chairs|CEA]] chair, and Shelton is a contender for [[Political_appointments_of_Donald_Trump#Vice_Chair_of_the_Federal_Reserve|Fed Vice-Chair]].)
===Informal presidential advisors=== In addition to his statutory advisory groups, Trump is also organizing efforts to directly communicate with business leaders.

The details of the December 2016 meeting were not made public, but according to anonymous sources, reforming the [[H1B visa]] program was discussed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-trump-immigration-tech-idUSKBN14W1CZ|title=Trump, tech tycoons talk overhaul of H1B visas|date=12 January 2017|publisher=|via=Reuters}}</ref>
Of the above, Stephen Bannon resigned on 18 August 2017; Reince Prebus was fired on 11 March 2017.
==== Business-oriented strategy and policy group ====
In addition to the tech-industry group, there is also a more general business advisory group being formed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2016/12/05/donald-trump-business-advisors-barra-rometty/|title=Mary Barra and Ginni Rometty Are On Trump's New Panel of CEO Advisors|first=Claire|last=Zillman|website=Fortune}}</ref> Billionaire [[Stephen Schwarzman]] of [[Blackstone Group|Blackstone]] organized the business advisory group, which also includes:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/tech/news/2016/12/14/ceos-tesla-uber-join-trumps-business-adviser-team/95416356/|title=Elon Musk, Uber's Kalanick join Trump's business adviser team|publisher=}}</ref>
* [[Paul S. Atkins|Paul Atkins]], former [[Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]] commissioner * [[Mary Barra]], CEO of [[General Motors|GM]] * [[Toby Cosgrove]], CEO of [[Cleveland Clinic]] * [[Jamie Dimon]], CEO of [[JPMorgan Chase]] * [[Laurence D. Fink|Larry Fink]], CEO of [[BlackRock]] * [[Travis Kalanick]], CEO of [[Uber (company)|Uber]] (December 2016-February 2017 resignation)<ref>{{cite news |last=Milliken |first=Grennan |url=http://motherboard.vice.com/read/trump-critic-elon-musk-now-named-to-presidential-advisory-team |title=Trump Critic Elon Musk Chosen for Presidential Advisory Team |work=Motherboard |publisher=Vice Media LLC |date=2016-12-14 |accessdate=2016-12-15 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/02/technology/uber-ceo-travis-kalanick-trump-advisory-council.html?_r=0|title=Uber C.E.O. to Leave Trump Advisory Council After Criticism|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> * [[Rich Lesser]], CEO of [[Boston Consulting Group|BCG]] * [[Doug McMillon]], CEO of [[Wal-Mart]] * [[Jim McNerney]], former CEO of [[Boeing]] * [[Elon Musk]] (December 2016-June 2017 resignation)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://greatagain.gov/president-elect-trump-announces-additional-members-of-presidents-strategic-and-policy-forum-8aa8822eced9#.4coc2gtxc|title=President-Elect Trump Announces Additional Members of President’s Strategic and Policy Forum|first=The Transition|last=Team|date=December 14, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=December 20, 2016}}</ref> * [[Indra Nooyi]], CEO of [[PepsiCo]] * [[Adebayo Ogunlesi|Bayo Ogunlesi]], chair of [[Global Infrastructure Partners]] * [[Ginni Rometty]], CEO of [[IBM]], also attended tech-CEO meeting * [[Kevin Warsh]], former [[Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System|FRB]] member * [[Mark Weinberger]], CEO of [[Ernst & Young|EY]] * [[Jack Welch]], former CEO of [[General Electric|GE]] * [[Daniel Yergin]], winner of the [[Pulitzer Prize]]
It is unclear whether Trump or his transition team have personally met with this advisory group, but media reports indicate that some of the members were considered for [[Cabinet of Donald Trump|cabinet-level]] positions in his administration (including Dimon as a potential treasury secretary, Cosgrove as potential secretary of veterans affairs, Warsh for a potential Federal Reserve role).

Sinda |revenue = USD$230 million (2016) |homepage = http://www.mscsoftware.com/ }} '''MSC Software Corporation''' is an American [[software]] company based in [[Newport Beach, California]], that specializes in [[Computer simulation|simulation]] software. In February 2017, the company was acquired by [[Sweden|Swedish]] technology company [[Hexagon AB]] for $834 million.https://www.reuters.com/article/deals-day-idUSL4N1FN2KN Reuters Deals ==History== MSC Software Corporation was formed in 1963 under the name MacNeal-Schwendler Corporation (MSC), by Dr Richard H. MacNeal and Robert Schwendler. The company developed its first structural analysis software called SADSAM (Structural Analysis by Digital Simulation of Analog Methods) at that time, and was deeply involved in the early efforts of the aerospace industry to improve early finite element analysis technology.{{cite web|url=http://www.mscsoftware.com/msc-software |title=MSC Software Company History |publisher=MSC Software Corporation |date= |accessdate=2013-02-06}} A key milestone was responding to a 1965 [[request for proposal]] (RFP) from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration ([[NASA]]) for a general purpose structural analysis program that would eventually become [[Nastran]] (NASA Structural Analysis). The company subsequently pioneered many of the technologies that are now relied upon by industry to analyze and predict stress and strain, vibration and dynamics, acoustics, and thermal analysis. In 1971, the company released a commercial version of Nastran, named MSC/Nastran.{{cite web|url=http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/The-MacNealSchwendler-Corporation-Company-History.html |title=History of The MacNeal-Schwendler Corporation |publisher=FundingUniverse.com |date= |accessdate=2013-02-06}} Two years after MSC began marketing MSC/Nastran, the company established its first overseas office in [[Munich, Germany]]. Three years after entering Europe, MSC moved eastward and opened an office in [[Tokyo, Japan]]. In 1983, MSC made its debut as a public company, and a year later the stock migrated to the [[American Stock Exchange]]. The company expanded in 1992 by adding a subsidiary in [[Moscow, Russia]]. In 1995, it further expanded its growth by adding an office in Brazil. In June 1999, MSC's stockholders voted to change the company's name to MSC.Software Corporation.{{cite web|url=http://web.mscsoftware.com/press/press.cfm?pid=444&div_id=1&non=1&arc=1&yid=1999 |title=The MacNeal-Schwendler Corporation Changes Name to MSC.Software Corporation |publisher=MSC Software Corporation |date=1999-06-23 |accessdate=2013-02-06}} In July 2009, MSC Software was acquired by the [[private equity firm]] [[Symphony Technology Group]].{{cite web|author=Steven M. Davidoff |url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2009/07/13/small-deals-big-issues/ |title=Small Deals, Big Issues |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |date=2009-07-13 |accessdate=2013-02-06}} The "dot" was dropped from the company's name in 2011 and the company's name is currently MSC Software Corporation. The company is headquartered in [[Newport Beach, California]] and employs approximately 1,300 people in 23 countries.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} 2016 revenue was USD$230 million. In February 2017, the company was acquired by Swedish engineering services conglomerate Hexagon.{{cite web|url=http://gfxspeak.com/2017/02/02/hexagon-acquire-software/ |title=Hexagon to acquire MSC Software for $834 million |website=gfxspeak.com |date=2009-12-04 |accessdate=2017-02-03}} == Acquisitions == September 1994 - PDA Engineering{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/MacNeal-Schwendler+names+former+PDA+executive,+Thomas+Curry,...-a016028617 |title=MacNeal-Schwendler names former PDA executive, Thomas Curry, president |publisher=TheFreeLibrary.com |date= |accessdate=2013-02-06}} May 1999 - MSC Software acquired MARC Analysis Research Corporation to add software that tests complex designs and materials.{{cite web|author=Published: May 29, 1999 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/05/29/business/company-news-macneal-schwendler-to-buy-marc-analysis-research.html |title=Company News; Macneal-Schwendler To Buy Marc Analysis Research - New York Times |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |date=1999-05-29 |accessdate=2013-02-06}} June 1999 - Universal Analytics Incorporation (UAI)[http://www.ftc.gov/os/adjpro/d9299/020701mscpfof.pdf "MSC.Software Corporation's Proposed Findings of Fact"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528200716/http://www.ftc.gov/os/adjpro/d9299/020701mscpfof.pdf |date=2010-05-28 }}, retrieved October 13, 2010 November 1999 - Computerized Structural Analysis Research Corporation (CSAR) May 2001 - Advanced Enterprise Solutions Inc. (AES).{{cite web|url=http://web.mscsoftware.com/press/press.cfm?pid=330&Div_ID=6 |title=MSC.Software to Acquire Advanced Enterprise Solutions, Inc. |publisher=MSC Software Corporation |date=2001-05-02 |accessdate=2013-02-06}} March 2002 - MSC Software acquired Mechanical Dynamics Inc. to increase its client base to over 10,000 companies.{{cite web|author=Published: March 19, 2002 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/03/19/business/technology-briefing-software-msc-will-buy-mechanical-dynamics.html |title=MSC Will Buy Mechanical Dynamics |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |date=2002-03-19 |accessdate=2013-02-06}} January 2008 - MSC Software acquired thermal analysis company Network Analysis Inc. to solidify its ability to serve the thermal management market.{{cite web | url=http://ocbiz.ocregister.com/2008/01/14/mscsoftware-buys-thermal-simulation-firm/1851/ | title=MSC.Software buys thermal simulation firm | publisher=Orange County Register | date=2008-01-14 | accessdate=2013-02-06 | author=Milbourn, Mary Ann}} September 2011 - MSC Software acquired acoustic simulation company Free Field Technologies, S.A. to extend its solutions to acoustic simulation {{cite web|url=http://www.schnitgercorp.com/SC/Hot_Topics/Entries/2011/9/6_MSC_acquires_FFT,_Actran.html |title=MSC acquires FFT, Actran |publisher=SchnitgerCorp.com |date=2011-09-06 |accessdate=2013-02-06}} September 2012 - MSC Software acquired composite material simulation leader e-Xstream engineering company.{{cite web |url=http://www.e-xstream.com/en/msc-software-acquires-composite-material-simulation-leader-e-xstream.html?cmp_id=17&news_id=566&vID=56 |title=MSC Software Acquires Composite Material Simulation Leader e-Xstream |publisher=E-xstream.com |date=2012-09-27 |accessdate=2013-02-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130122033033/http://www.e-xstream.com/en/msc-software-acquires-composite-material-simulation-leader-e-xstream.html?cmp_id=17&news_id=566&vID=56 |archivedate=2013-01-22 |df= }} February 2015 - MSC Software acquired Simufact Engineering leader in simulation of metal forming and joining processes.{{cite web|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/msc-software-acquires-welding-forming-130000103.html |title=MSC Software Acquires Welding and Forming Simulation Leader Simufact |publisher=finance.yahoo.com |date=2015-02-18 |accessdate=2015-02-18}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ;Notes *"Competition, Defense Industry Cuts Hurt Price of MacNeal-Schwendler Corp. {{Infobox venue | name = Maxwell Chambers | former names = Custom House (1932 to 2010) | logo_image = MClogo colored.jpg | image = Maxwell Chambers Exterior - Day.jpg | address = 32 Maxwell Road Singapore 069115 | location = [[Singapore]] | coordinates = {{Coord|1|16|39.5|N|103|50|46.1|E|display=inline,title}} | type = Historic site, events venue | built = 1932 (as Custom House) | opened = {{Start date|2010|01|df=y}} (as Maxwell Chambers) | publictransit = [[Tanjong Pagar MRT Station|Tanjong Pagar MRT]] | website = [http://maxwell-chambers.com maxwell-chambers.com] }} '''Maxwell Chambers''' is an integrated [[alternative dispute resolution]] (ADR) complex located in [[Singapore]]. It provides hearing rooms and facilities for the conduct of ADR hearings in Singapore, as well as the regional offices of a number of ADR institutions, [[arbitral tribunal|arbitrators]], and [[international arbitration]] practitioners.<ref name="Singapore’s legal edge">{{cite news|last1=Teo|first1=Xuanwei|title=Singapore’s legal edge|agency=TODAY|date=22 January 2010}}</ref>
Maxwell Chambers was established with [[seed money]] from the [[Government of Singapore|Singapore Government]]. The intention is for ownership to transfer to the [[private sector]] in due course.<ref name="Asia's arbitration explosion">{{cite web|last1=Crowe|first1=Chris|title=Asia's arbitration explosion|date=16 August 2010|url=http://www.ibanet.org/Article/Detail.aspx?ArticleUid=C55383E1-519F-4CD9-8822-BE34CC748D2F|website=International Bar Association|accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref>
In January 2017, the [[Ministry of Law (Singapore)|Ministry of Law]] announced that it was planning to expand the current size of Maxwell Chambers with [[#Maxwell Chambers Suites|Maxwell Chambers Suites]] in a bid to boost Singapore's position as an international dispute resolution hub.<ref name=MC1>{{cite web|title=Maxwell Chambers to expand, will take over building that houses Red Dot Design Museum|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/maxwell-chambers-to-expand-will-take-over-building-that-houses-red-dot-design|website=The Straits Times|publisher=The Straits Times}}</ref>
==History==
The origins of Maxwell Chambers can be traced as far back as 2002 when the Legal Services Working Group of the Economic Review Committee chaired by then Deputy Prime Minister [[Lee Hsien Loong]] stressed the need for “good infrastructure and facilities” to make Singapore a regional alternative dispute resolution service centre.<ref name="The Asia Pacific Arbitration Review 2014">{{cite journal|last1=Ahmad|first1=Jawad|last2=Yeap|first2=Andre|title=Section 2: Overviews - Arbitration in Asia|journal=The Asia Pacific Arbitration Review 2014|url=http://globalarbitrationreview.com/reviews/55/sections/193/chapters/2165/arbitration-asia/|accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref>
In 2005, the [[Ministry of Law (Singapore)|Ministry of Law]] started planning for the development of an integrated dispute resolution complex. The architects visited arbitration hearing centres around the world to get design ideas, and then added “a Singapore touch”.<ref name="Maxwell Chambers opens in Singapore">{{cite journal|last1=Sulaiman|first1=Uzma Balkiss|title=Maxwell Chambers opens in Singapore|journal=Global Arbitration Review|date=7 February 2010|volume=5|issue=1|url=http://globalarbitrationreview.com/journal/article/27663/maxwell-chambers-opens-singapore}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
In January 2007, Singapore's former Custom House was chosen as the site<ref name="Asia's arbitration explosion" /> and design work commenced. Upon the completion of refurbishment works in July 2009, the building opened for hearings.
Maxwell Chambers was officially launched in January 2010.<ref name="Maxwell Chambers opens in Singapore" />
==Reception==
The establishment of Maxwell Chambers was nominated by Global Arbitration Review (GAR) as one of the “Best Developments” in the arbitration industry in 2010.<ref name="Singapore: City state reflects on progress">{{cite journal|last1=Ross|first1=Alison|title=Singapore: City state reflects on progress|journal=Global Arbitration Review|date=5 June 2011|volume=6|issue=3|url=http://globalarbitrationreview.com/journal/article/29602/singapore-city-state-reflects-progress}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
GAR's first survey on hearing centres in 2013 found that Maxwell Chambers was one of the top three hearing centres that leading international arbitration lawyers were most likely to "recommend to a friend". Survey respondents remarked that Maxwell Chambers was “perfect”, “the standout facility” and “currently the gold standard”.<ref name="Hearing Centres Survey">{{cite journal|last1=Samuels|first1=David|title=Hearing Centres Survey|journal=Global Arbitration Review's Guide to Regional Arbitration|date=4 February 2014|volume=2|url=http://globalarbitrationreview.com/regional-arbitration/directory/4/article/32364/hearing-centres-survey/|accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref>
In GAR's Hearing Centres Survey for 2016, Maxwell Chambers was ranked second for most of the key factors respondents look out for in choosing a hearing centre, such as location, IT services, and helpfulness of staff.<ref>{{cite web|title=Guide To Regional Arbitration (volume 4 - 2016)|url=http://globalarbitrationreview.com/edition/1000140/guide-to-regional-arbitration-volume-4-2016|website=Global Arbitration Review|publisher=Global Arbitration Review}}</ref>
==Building==
Maxwell Chambers occupies the former Custom House located in [[Tanjong Pagar]] in Singapore's central business district. Built in the 1930s during the British colonial era, the building was the headquarters of the [[Singapore Customs|Department of Customs and Excise]] for over 60 years.<ref name="The Building that Never Slept">{{cite journal|title=The Building that Never Slept|journal=inSYNC - Singapore Customs Newsletter|date=January 2011|issue=10|url=http://www.customs.gov.sg/insync/issue10/thebuildingthatneverslept.html}}</ref> Following the refurbishment of the building, it was renamed Maxwell Chambers and was in 2010 marked the 88th historic site in Singapore by the [[National Heritage Board (Singapore)|National Heritage Board]].<ref name="Custom House marked as a historic site">{{cite news|last1=Spykerman|first1=Kimberly|title=Custom House marked as a historic site|agency=The Straits Times|date=9 October 2010}}</ref>
The building was awarded the International Architecture Award for Best New Global Design (2010) by The Chicago Athenaeum Museum of Architecture and Design and the European Centre for Architecture Art Design and Urban Studies.<ref name="The International Architectural Awards 2010 Archive">{{cite book|title=The International Architectural Awards 2010 Archive|date=2010|publisher=The Chicago Athenaeum Museum of Architecture and Design|page=62|url=https://chi-athenaeum.org/assets/pdf_archives/intarch/archive-2010-International-Arch-awards.pdf}}</ref> In 2012, the building was also awarded an Architectural Heritage Award by Singapore's [[Urban Redevelopment Authority]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wong|first1=Jeanne|title=Maxwell Chambers wins URA Architectural Heritage Award|url=http://news.asiaone.com/News/Latest+News/Singapore/Story/A1Story20121005-375805.html|accessdate=4 August 2014|agency=AsiaOne|date=5 October 2012}}</ref>
===Maxwell Chambers Suites===
The [[Ministry of Law (Singapore)|Ministry of Law]] announced in January 2017 that Maxwell Chambers would triple in capacity by taking over the neighbouring building at 28 Maxwell Road (formerly known as the Red Dot Traffic Building), in order to support the growth of dispute resolution institutions which have seen significant increases in caseload.<ref name=MC1 />
At the official groundbreaking ceremony in June 2017, the Ministry of Law announced that the new offices at 28 Maxwell Road would be renamed Maxwell Chambers Suites. It was also announced the Suites would be expanding even further due to "strong demand", with a second annexe block to add 3,500 sq ft of space, on top of the 120,000 sq ft expansion that was originally planned.<ref name=MC2>{{cite web|title=Strong demand drives further expansion at Maxwell Chambers|url=http://www.businesstimes.com.sg/real-estate/strong-demand-drives-further-expansion-at-maxwell-chambers|website=The Business Times|publisher=The Business Times}}</ref>
The new Maxwell Chambers Suites will provide a new 24-hour public thoroughfare that will allow pedestrian access between [[Tanjong Pagar MRT station]] and the [[Chinatown, Singapore|Chinatown]] area. These two areas are currently separated by the 161-metre long building along Maxwell Road. Maxwell Chambers Suites will also house four floors of about 50 new offices for international dispute resolution institutions, arbitration chambers, law firms and ancillary legal services.
Restoration works are currently underway and expected to be completed in 2019.<ref name=MC2 />
==Facilities==
Maxwell Chambers has 10 custom-designed and fully equipped hearing rooms and 12 preparation rooms, a business centre,<ref name="New integrated dispute resolution complex opens in Singapore">{{cite news|last1=Yeo|first1=Alvin|last2=Maniam|first2=Andre|title=New integrated dispute resolution complex opens in Singapore|url=http://uk.practicallaw.com/0-501-4054?service=arbitration|accessdate=4 August 2014|agency=Practical Law|date=4 February 2010}}</ref> and a lounge for arbitrators.<ref name="Maxwell Chambers opens in Singapore" /> It also provides audio-visual and [[Videoconferencing|video conferencing]] facilities and [[Language interpretation|simultaneous translation]] and [[Transcription (service)|transcription]].<ref name="New integrated dispute resolution complex opens in Singapore" />
==Tenants==
Maxwell Chambers houses the regional offices of several ADR institutions<ref name="The Asia Pacific Arbitration Review 2014" /> including the [[Singapore International Arbitration Centre]] (SIAC), the [[Singapore International Mediation Centre]] (SIMC), the [[International Court of Arbitration|ICC Court of Arbitration]], the [[American Arbitration Association]]’s (AAA) International Centre for Dispute Resolution (ICDR), the [[World Intellectual Property Organization]] (WIPO) Arbitration and Mediation Center, and the Singapore Chamber of Maritime Arbitration (SCMA). The Singapore International Mediation Centre (SIMC) will also be based at Maxwell Chambers.<ref name='Back to "MediAsian"'>{{cite web|last1=Lim|first1=George|title=Back to "MediAsian"|url=http://whoswholegal.com/news/features/article/31678/back-mediasian/|website=Who's Who Legal|accessdate=4 August 2014}}</ref>
A number of barristers’ chambers and arbitrators have a regional office at Maxwell Chambers including [[Essex Court Chambers]], [http://www.20essexst.com 20 Essex Street],<ref name="MoJ oversight costs London dear">{{cite news|title=MoJ oversight costs London dear|url=http://www.thelawyer.com/analysis/notebook/moj-oversight-costs-london-dear/3007267.article|accessdate=4 August 2014|agency=The Lawyer|date=15 July 2013}}</ref> [[39 Essex Chambers]], [[One Essex Court]],<ref name="One Essex Court and 39 Essex Street prepare for Singapore launches">{{cite news|last1=Dowell|first1=Katy|title=One Essex Court and 39 Essex Street prepare for Singapore launches|url=http://www.thelawyer.com/one-essex-court-and-39-essex-street-prepare-for-singapore-launches/1013086.article|accessdate=4 August 2014|agency=The Lawyer|date=26 June 2012}}</ref> [http://www.bankside.co.nz Bankside Chambers]<ref name="New Zealand trio set up shop in Maxwell Chambers’">{{cite news|last1=Elward|first1=David|title=New Zealand trio set up shop in Maxwell Chambers’|url=http://www.globalarbitrationreview.com/news/article/29285/new-zealand-trio-set-shop-maxwell-chambers/|agency=Global Arbitration Review|date=28 February 2011}}{{subscription required}}</ref> and [http://www.hvdb.com Hanotiau & van den Berg]<ref name="Boutique firm to gain Singapore outpost">{{cite news|last1=Alison|first1=Ross|title=Boutique firm to gain Singapore outpost|url=http://www.globalarbitrationreview.com/news/article/30031/boutique-firm-gain-singapore-outpost/|agency=Global Arbitration Review|date=9 December 2011}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
==Signature Events==
In addition to providing hearing facilities and office space, Maxwell Chambers also organises a number of signature events: *Singapore International Arbitration Forum (SIAF) *Maxwell ADR Forum * Maxwell Lectures

{{other people|Michael Evans}} '''Michael Evans''' is the CEO and Co-Founder of [[The Vines of Mendoza]]. Evans served on the [[John Kerry presidential campaign, 2004|John Kerry]] presidential campaign,<ref>By Helen Coster. (3-1-10). Harvesting Profits in Argentina's Wine Country. https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2010/0301/second-acts-wine-mendoza-malbec-planting-roots_2.html Retrieved on 9-28-10.</ref> and was COO of the [[Rock the Vote|Rock The Vote]] Campaign.<ref>By Daniel Terdiman. (3-11-04) Cell Phones to Democracy's Rescue. https://www.wired.com/politics/law/news/2004/03/62611. Wired. Retrieved on 10-7-10.</ref> He was also previously Executive Director of [[CTIA – The Wireless Association|CTIA Foundation]], an international association for the wireless telecommunications industry and ran business development for iNetnow,<ref>(10-9-00). Human Voice Portal iNetNow Taps Former CTIA Executive Michael Evans to Join Business Development Team. http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Human+Voice+Portal+iNetNow+Taps+Former+CTIA+Executive+Michael+Evans...-a065846797 BusinessWire. Retrieved on 10-5-10.</ref> a start-up Web-based concierge service in 2000. Evans is also a [[photographer]].<ref>Michael Evans SmugMug Page. http://michaelhevans.smugmug.com/ Retrieved on 9-27-10.</ref>
==The Vines of Mendoza== Evans, a former technology and political executive, went on vacation to Mendoza, Argentina in 2004. Shortly after meeting his business partner [[Pablo Gimenez Riili]], they formed The Vines of Mendoza together.<ref>By Helen Coster. (3-1-10). Harvesting Profits in Argentina's Wine Country. https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2010/0301/second-acts-wine-mendoza-malbec-planting-roots_2.html Retrieved on 9-28-10.</ref>
With Riili, Evans raised money from friends and family, purchased 900 acres of land in the [[Uco Valley]], and created The Vines of Mendoza’s private vineyard estates.<ref>By Helen Coster. (3-1-10). Harvesting Profits in Argentina's Wine Country. https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2010/0301/second-acts-wine-mendoza-malbec-planting-roots_2.html Retrieved on 9-28-10.</ref><ref>By Ryan Flinn.(12-31-09). Texas Boy Can't Resist Taste of New Argentine Winery. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2009-12-31/-texas-boy-investor-can-t-resist-taste-of-new-argentine-winery.html. Retrieved on 10-5-10.</ref>
Evans and Riili also established The Vines of Mendoza Tasting Room that provides 100 [[Argentine]] wines in one location. The Acequia Wine Club and The Vines Online Wine Store were also created at that time.<ref>By Helen Coster. (3-1-10). Harvesting Profits in Argentina's Wine Country. https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2010/0301/second-acts-wine-mendoza-malbec-planting-roots_2.html Retrieved on 9-28-10.</ref><ref>Cava Argentina. (8-6-08). Pablo Gimenez Riili: Foreigners Fall in Love With Mendoza's People, Food, Wine & Climate. http://cavaargentina.com/es/news/pablo-gimenez-riili-foreigners-fall-in-love-with-mendoza-s-people-food-wine-and-climate.html</ref>

Athina Revidies | website = | years active = 1975–2017 |}} '''Minos Xenophon''' "'''Minas'''" '''Kyriakou''' ({{lang-el|Μίνως (Μηνάς) Κυριακού}}, {{IPA-el|ˌminos (miˌnas) ciriaˈku|pron}}; 31 May 1942 – 2 July 2017){{cite web|url=https://www.iaaf.org/news/news/minos-kyriakou|title=IAAF: Minos Kyriakou- News - iaaf.org|publisher=|accessdate=10 September 2016}} was a Greek media and [[shipping magnate]] and businessman. He was the president of the [[Hellenic Olympic Committee]]{{cite web|url=http://www.zoominfo.com/p/Minos-Kyriakou/4116367|title=Minos Kyriakou - Aegean Foundation - ZoomInfo.com|publisher=|accessdate=10 September 2016}} and was the President of the [[International Olympic Academy]] (IOA, 2004-2009). He was elected to the [[International Association of Athletics Federations|International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF)]] council in August 2003.{{cite web|url=http://www.iaaf.org/aboutiaaf/news/newsid=23318.html|title=IAAF: News - iaaf.org|publisher=|accessdate=10 September 2016}} ==Early life== Minos Kyriakou is the son of Xenophon Kyriacou and Athina Revidies.{{cite book|author=Europa Publications|title=The International Who's Who 2004|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sR4Ch1dMe8IC&pg=PA942|accessdate=3 July 2017|year=2003|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-1-85743-217-6|page=942}} He was educated in France, Switzerland and at [[Columbia University]] in the US, from where he has a bachelor's degree. ==Career== Kyriakou was the founder and owner of [[ANT1 Group]], a media company which owns most notably [[ANT1]], one of the oldest and one of the first private television channels in Greece. He also owned the Greek [[sports club|multi-sports club]] [[Panellinios GS]], and the [[Greek Basket League]] club [[Panellinios BC|Panellinios]]. Kyriakou's links to the sporting world saw him later become president of the Greek Olympic Committee after Athens hosted the Olympic Games of 2004. He continued as president before stepping down in 2009. https://hellenicnews.com/greek-owner-minos-kyriakou-dies-aged-75/ ==Problems with the law== Kyriakou owned four acres of land in [[Athens]] that are in violation of Areos Park, as some of the [[Panellinios Athens]] complexes are illegally on the premises of the [[Athens Municipality]] and the [[Athens Prefecture]]. In February 2007, a penalty of 48 months imprisonment without suspension, and a fine of [[Euro sign|€]]15,000 [[euros]] was placed on Kyriakou for the arbitrary construction of a cottage property in San Aimilianos in [[Porto Heli]]. Namely, the construction of a harbor that was in violation of not only the winter tide, but also the future expansion of the coastline. As a result of this, Kyriakou appealed the ruling of the court and he was then asked to pay a fee of €100,000 euros in financial security costs until the appeal trial could be held.{{cite web|url=http://www.paron.gr/v3/new.php?id=12473&colid=&catid=28&dt=2007-02-11%200:0:0|title=TO ΠΑΡΟΝ ΤΗΣ ΚΥΡΙΑΚΗΣ|publisher=|accessdate=10 September 2016}}[http://news.kathimerini.gr/4dcgi/_w_articles_ell_2_29/03/2008_264467 News.kathimerini.gr - Εγγύηση Κυριακού μέχρι τη δίκη. {{el icon}}] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120711110713/http://news.kathimerini.gr/4dcgi/_w_articles_ell_2_29/03/2008_264467 |date=11 July 2012 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.galera.gr/magazine/modules/articles/article.php?id=715|title=Account Suspended|publisher=|accessdate=10 September 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303025657/http://www.galera.gr/magazine/modules/articles/article.php?id=715|archivedate=3 March 2012|df=dmy-all}} ==Personal life== In December 2004, Kyriakou married the Greek actress Mari Konstantatou (b. 1971).{{cite web|url=http://www.musicheaven.gr/html/modules.php?name=Blog&file=page&op=viewPost&pid=19573|title=Μίνως Κυριακού ο φασίστας - Βιογραφία - Νεοέλληνας..|publisher=|accessdate=10 September 2016}} They announced their divorce in March 2017.{{cite web|author=A.I. |url=http://www.athens-times.com/greece/minos-kyriakou-what-kind-of-diet-will-give-to-marie-after-the-divorce/ |title=Minos Kyriakou: What kind of diet will give to Marie after the divorce? |publisher=Athens Times |date=9 March 2017 |accessdate=3 July 2017}}{{cite web|author=John Simpson |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/billionaires-wife-fled-on-private-jet-with-a-stash-of-family-jewels-mvrsv88gd |title=Billionaire’s wife ‘fled on private jet with a stash of family jewels’ | News | The Times & The Sunday Times |publisher=Thetimes.co.uk |date=20 March 2017 |accessdate=3 July 2017}} He had two sons, [[Xenophon Kyriakou|Xenophon]] and [[Theodore Kyriakou|Theodore]], and a daughter, Athina, from his first marriage.{{cite web|url=http://www.mlahanas.de/Greeks/NewEnterprise/MinosKyriakou.html|title=Minos Kyriakou|publisher=|accessdate=10 September 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304202231/http://www.mlahanas.de/Greeks/NewEnterprise/MinosKyriakou.html|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} He spoke Greek, English, French, Italian, Spanish, Polish, and Russian. He was awarded the Golden Cross of the Legion of Honor – Republic of Poland, Golden Cross of the order of St. George, Golden Medal of Honor – Republic of Cyprus, Golden Star of Honor – Singapore Republic, Grand Cross of the Order of the Legion of Honor – Republic of Poland. Kyriakou died of a heart attack on 2 July 2017, at the Athens Medical Center.{{cite web |last=Associated |first=The |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/greek-mogul-sports-administrator-minos-kyriakou-dies-75-48409153 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170706073529/http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/greek-mogul-sports-administrator-minos-kyriakou-dies-75-48409153 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 July 2017 |title=Former Greek Olympic Committee President Minos Kyriakou dies - ABC News |publisher=Abcnews.go.com |date=6 December 2005 |accessdate=3 July 2017 }} He was twice divorced and was survived by his three children from his first marriage. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://archive.is/20130108001125/http://www.antennagroup.gr/ Antenna Group's Official Site] {{gr icon}}/{{en icon}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100111064156/http://www.atheniangroup.com/main.htm Athenian Sea Carriers Ltd] {{ANT1 Group}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kyriakou, Minos}} [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:Panellinios]] [[Category:Greek businesspeople]] [[Category:Greek billionaires]] [[Category:Greek businesspeople in shipping]] [[Category:ANT1 Group]]

'''Ndidi Nnoli-Edozien''' Ph.D (born July 31, 1972) is a Nigerian [[Social entrepreneurship|social entrepreneur]] and [[Corporate social responsibility|corporate sustainability and responsibility]] (CSR) expert and [[Bottom of the Pyramid]] empowerment advocate. She is the Founder and President of the Growing Businesses Foundation, Nigeria’s largest [[Bottom of the Pyramid]] platform which has been managing CSR Projects for multinational corporations. Her status as a social entrepreneur has been recognized by the Bertelsmann AG to whom she is affiliated as a Reinhard Mohn Fellow.
At the Africa Conference on Women in Governance, Business and Community Leadership and Women of Influence Awards in London 2010, she received the African Star Excellence Award in Business Development. A member of the [[International Finance Corporation]] (IFC), Nnoli-Edozien has contributed to policy reforms in Nigeria through her work with government ministries and agencies.
==Education==
Nnoli-Edozien was born in Karlsruhe City in Germany and she graduated from [[Queen's College, Lagos|Queen’s College Lagos]] in 1989 and studied at the [[London School of Economics|London School of Economics and Political Science]], United Kingdom earning a BSc in Economics. Nnoli-Edozien gained her Master’s Degree from [[Goethe University Frankfurt|Johann Wolfgang Goethe University]], Frankfurt am Main, Germany in Catholic Theology before undertaking her PhD at the [[Goethe University Frankfurt|Johann Wolfgang Goethe University]] in the area of “ownership and management structures” with a global focus on the global applicability of African Models of Corporate Governance and Sustainability.
She is an alumnus of the Wharton Business School and has attended executive programmes at INSEAD and the Judge Business School, Cambridge. She teaches, part-time, ethics, social entrepreneurship and sustainability at the Lagos Business School
==Career==
October 1999, Nnoli-Edozien founded the Growing Businesses Foundation as a platform to support enterprise development at the Bottom of the Pyramid in Nigeria.
In January 2001, Nnoli-Edozien founded the Micro-enterprise Development Co-operation, MDC is a platform for evaluating international best practices in micro-finance for building self-reliant and sustainable financial intermediaries that nurture and grow small businesses into viable and socially responsible service providers.
From November 2004 to December 2005, Nnoli-Edozien served as the African Representative of the Bank für Orden und Mission, Germany
In January 2011, she joined the Central Organizing Committee of the [[Nigerian Economic Summit Group]] (NESG)
In April 2011, Nnoli- Edozien accepted to become a member of the National Committee on Job Creation in Nigeria which was chaired by [[Aliko Dangote]] and inaugurated to develop an action plan for job creation in Nigeria.
In January, 2012 Nnoli-Edozien was nominated by the International Finance Corporation as a Director of AB Microfinance Nigeria.
In February 2012, she was appointed by the Federal Ministry of Communication Technology as part of a team member convened by the Honourable Minister of ICT to draft a comprehensive ICT policy for Nigeria.
==Assignments==
Nnoli-Edozien currently serves as a board member of the [[United World Colleges]] National Committee in Nigeria and is responsible for Alumni, fundraising and student selection.
As a current member of the [[tt30|tt30 Club of Rome]], Nnoli-Edozien has been responsible for logistics and fundraising for events including the tt30 Club of Rome 2006 Conference and subsequently the Digital World Africa Conference.
In July 2010, Nnoli-Edozien was appointed member of the National Committee on Job Creation by the Federal Ministry of Finance, Nigeria to develop an action plan on job creation in Nigeria.
In February 2012, Nnoli-Edozien was selected to be a member of a team responsible for drafting a comprehensive ICT policy for Nigeria by the Federal Ministry of Communication Technology.
Nnoli-Edozien was the secretary of the South-South Economic Summit in Nigeria held in 2012.

|chief2_name = |chief2_position = |agency_type = |parent_department = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |keydocument1 = |website = {{URL|www.pemra.gov.pk}} |footnotes = |map = |map_width = |map_caption = }} '''Pakistan Electronic Media Regulatory Authority ''' ({{lang-ur|{{Nastaliq|'''پاکستان الیکٹرانک ذرائع ابلاغ انضباطی اختیار'''}}}}, [[Reporting name|reporting name:]] '''PEMRA'''), is an independent and constitutionally established [[Government institution|federal institution]] responsible for regulating and issuing channel licenses for establishment of the [[media culture|mass media culture]], print and electronic media.{{cite web|last=CoP|title=Introduction of Pemra|publisher=Government of Pakistan|accessdate=12 February 2013|url=http://www.pemra.gov.pk/pemra/}} Codified under the Article 19: Chapter I{{cite web|url=http://www.pakistani.org/pakistan/constitution/part2.ch1.html|title=Chapter 1: "Fundamental Rights" of Part II: "Fundamental Rights and Principles of Policy"|work=pakistani.org}} of the [[Constitution of Pakistan]], it has jurisdiction to impose reasonable restrictions in the interest of the religion, the integrity, national security of Pakistan. Established on March 1, 2002, Pemra's principal objectives are to facilitate and regulate the private electronic mass-media industry and to improve the standards of information, education and entertainment.{{cite web|title=Ordnance 2002|url=http://www.pemra.gov.pk/pemra/images/docs/legislation/Ordinance_2002.pdf|work=Constitution of Pakistan|publisher=Constitution of Pakistan|accessdate=12 February 2013}} Its constitutional mandate is to enlarge the choice available to the people of Pakistan including [[news]], [[current events|current affairs]], religious knowledge, [[art]] and [[culture]] as well as science and technology.{{cite web|last=Pemra|title=Mandate of Pemra|url=http://www.pemra.gov.pk/pemra/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1&Itemid=2|publisher=PEMra|accessdate=12 February 2013}} On 28 June 2018 after the Supreme Court's order Saleem Baig was appointed as the Chairman of PEMRA{{cite web|url=https://www.geo.tv/latest/201092-mirza-saleem-baig-appointed-pemra-chairman|title=Mirza Saleem Baig appointed PEMRA chairman|publisher=|accessdate=10 July 2018}} ==Constitutional status and definition== The constitutional freedom of speech and press are highlighted in the constitution of Pakistan. Under the Article 19 and Article 19A of Fundamental Rights in the Constitution of Pakistan. The Constitution grants PEMRA following powers: # Improve the standards of information, education and entertainment. #Enlarge the choice available to the people of Pakistan in the media for news, current affairs, religious knowledge, art, culture, science, technology, economic development, social sector concerns, music, sports, drama and other subjects of public and national interest. #Facilitate the devolution of responsibility and power to the grass roots by improving the access of the people to mass media at the local and community level. #Ensure accountability, transparency and good governance by optimization in the free flow of information. {{centered pull quote|text=Every citizen shall have the right to freedom of speech and expression, and there shall be freedom of the press, subject to any reasonable restrictions imposed by law in the interest of the glory of Islam or the integrity, security or defense of Pakistan or any part thereof, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, or in relation to contempt of court, [commission of] or incitement to an offence. Article 19(A)— Right to information: Every citizen shall have the right to have access to information in all matters of public importance subject to regulation and reasonable restrictions imposed by law. |author=Article 19-19(A): Fundamental Rights and Principles of Policy; Part-II, Chapter 1: Fundamental Rights |source=source: The [[Constitution of Pakistan]]{{cite web|title=Chapter 1: Freedom of Speech and Press |url=http://www.pakistani.org/pakistan/constitution/part2.ch1.html|publisher=Constitution of Pakistan|accessdate=3 January 2013}}}} ==Overview== The Authority is responsible for facilitating and regulating the establishment and operation of all private broadcast media and distribution services in Pakistan established for the purpose of international, national, provincial, district, and local or special target audiences. ==History== The Pakistan Electronic Media Regulatory Authority (PEMRA) was promoted by the government as an open media policy reform and was fortified with strong regulatory teeth. The establishment of PEMRA was initiated in 2000, during President Musharraf's term; through the formation of the Regulatory Authority for Media Broadcast Organisations (RAMBO) which was mandated to improve standards of information, education and entertainment; expand the choice available to the people of Pakistan in the media for news, current affairs, religions knowledge, art, culture, science, technology, economic development, social sector concerns, music, sport, drama and other subjects of public and national interest; facilitate the devolution of responsibility and power to grass roots by improving the access to mass media at the local and community level; and lastly, to ensure accountability, transparency and good governance by optimising the free flow of information. Many pro-democratic campaigners consider this four-point mandate to be a solid foundation supporting democracy processes and comprehensive media liberalisation. However, the general opinion among media practitioners is that PEMRA only acted as a licence issuing office that has implemented regulatory barriers for broadcasters. "It is a Bhatta (money extortion in [[Urdu]]) body that collects money from broadcasting operators in a legal way. Nothing more can be expected." notes media law activist and journalist Matiullah Jan. The PEMRA laws were utilized by the [[Pervez Musharraf|Musharraf]] regime in his attempts to tame the media. Some stations were shut down and some were under severe harassments using these laws. The 12-member authority was dominated by bureaucrats and ex-police officers - a phenomenon that had been partly changed after the assumption of office by the present government. However, media activists are still not comfortable with the composition of the 12-member committee where they highlight the need of a greater representation from the media itself. "Regulation of the TV and Radio should be through the participation and representation of the stake holders. What must happen is the restructuring of the Board of PEMRA with independent eminent people. It is still full of bureaucrats and ex-policemen, so there you find lack of ownership." says Maitullah Jan. PEMRA's leadership agree to that the institution needs to be more engaged with its stakeholders. "It's a combination of regulator and the stakeholders. Therefore, the chain is - Law/Regulator/Stakeholder," says Dr. Abdul Jabbar, the Executive Member of PEMRA. However, the present government is under pressure to amend or repeal these laws. Many media practitioners confirmed that the harsh use of the PEMRA laws during the Musharraf regime had not occurred during the past years. The PEMRA board has been reconstituted to some extent and includes some media professionals. Furthermore, the government is making some attempts to reintroduce some democratic norms in its media regulation reform. The Code of Conduct made by PEMRA has been subjected to criticism by the industry players, and is now being reviewed by the government. The former Minister of Information has requested Pakistani Broadcasters Association to draft a new Code of Conduct to replace the existing Code of Conduct of PEMRA. Still, a somewhat top-down approach is taken from PEMRA authorities on this matter. Referring to the issue of Code of Conduct, Dr. Abdul Jabbar said that presently there are many Codes of Conduct, one by PFUJ, one by South Asia Free Media Association (SAFMA) and the broadcasters are in the process of formulating another. "The Government will not agree to any of these, most probably. But taking all these documents into account, the government will come up with a comprehensive document that can be acceptable to all stakeholders. Then everybody has the ownership." He continued: "PEMRA will function - it will not be silenced or nullified. We will be the regulatory body. But the stakeholders will have a say in the Code of Conduct. That's what we call self-regulation."{{cite web |url=http://www.i-m-s.dk/files/publications/1491%20Pakistan.final.web.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091229205633/http://www.i-m-s.dk/files/publications/1491%20Pakistan.final.web.pdf |archivedate=29 December 2009 |df=dmy-all }} == Chairman of the Authority == '''Pete Power''' (born 1969) is the CEO of [[Angkor Mikroheranhvatho Kampuchea|Angkor Mikroheranhvatho (Kampuchea) Co.]] (AMK), the largest [[microfinance]] institution in [[Cambodia]] in terms of borrower numbers.<ref>AMK Cambodia. http://www.amkcambodia.com/?page=detail&menu1=4&article=4&lg=en</ref> AMK currently provides credit to about 300,000 customers or 10% of the households in Cambodia. Power successfully led AMK and its 1,000 staff through the [[Late-2000s financial crisis|global economic downturn]] and subsequently embarked on a strategic transformation process to change AMK from a rural credit-only organization to a provider of a broad range of financial services, including [[saving]]s, [[microcredit|credit]], money transfers, [[mobile banking]], and various other innovative financial services.<ref>Artese, Valerie. Microfinance Focus. Nov 4, 2011. http://www.microfinancefocus.com/amk-cambodias-managed-commitment-poor</ref>
==Biography==
Pwer grew up on a dairy farm in [[Rathgormack]], [[County Waterford]], [[Ireland]] and attended Rockwell College high school. He was award the first Dermot Harris Memorial Scholarship to the [[University of Scranton]].<ref>The Vindicator. Nov 17, 1987: Youngstown, OH. https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DC1KAAAAIBAJ&sjid=wIUMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4517,206921&dq=richard+harris+university+of+scranton&hl=en</ref> Power earned a Bachelor of Science in International Relations and Philosophy from the University of Scranton, followed by an MA in European Integration from the [[University of Limerick]].
In 2002, Power co-founded a specialty consulting and software company, Claritee Group.<ref>Claritee Group. http://www.clariteegroup.com/index.html</ref> Claritee focused on corporate performance management solutions. After building the company to over $3 million in revenue, Power left Claritee in 2005 and joined the NGO sector.
Power worked as the Financial Systems Manager for [[Concern Worldwide]] until 2009 when he became Chief Operating Officer at Prosperity Initiative, a private sector development NGO based in [[Hanoi]], [[Vietnam]].<ref>Prosperity Initiative. prosperityinitiative.org</ref> In 2010, Power joined AMK as CEO.
Power is a longtime rugby player, having been associated with Blackthorn Rugby Club for over 20 years.<ref>Blackthorn Rugby Club. http://www.pitchero.com/clubs/blackthornrugbyfootballclub/</ref>
Power is a regular conference speaker and media commentator on topics such as Microfinance, Business Technology, Globalization, and Project Management.
